play.title:
PERICLES, PRINCE of Tyre.
With the true Relation of the whole History, Adventures,
and Fortunes of the ſaid Prince.

line.italic: To ſing a ſong that old was ſung,

speech.line: From aſhes ancient Gower is come,

line.italic: Aſſuming mans infirmities,
To glad your ear and pleaſe your eyes;
It hath been ſung at Feſtivals,
On Ember eves, and holy-dayes,
And Lords and Ladies in their lives,
Have read it for reſtoratives.
The purchaſe is to make men glorious,

speech.line: Et bonum quo Antiquius, eo melius.

line.italic: If you, born in theſe latter times,
When wits more ripe, accept my Rimes;
And that to hear an old man ſing,
May to your wiſhes pleaſure bring:
I life would wiſh, and that I might
Waſte it for you like Taper-light.

speech.line: This Antioch, then, Antiochus the great,

line.italic: Built up this City for his chiefeſt ſeat;

speech.line: The faireſt in all Syria.

line.italic: I tell you what mine Authors ſay:
This King unto him took a Peer,
Who died, and left a female heir,
So bucksome, blithe, and full of face,
As heaven had lent her all his grace:
With whom the Father liking took,
And her to inceſt did provoke.
Bad childe, worſe father, to entice his own.
To evil ſhould be done by none:
But cuſtome, what they did begin,
Was with long uſe, counted no ſin.
The beauty of this ſinfull Dame,
Made many princes thither frame,
To ſeek her as a bed-fellow,
In marriage pleaſures, play-fellow:
Which to prevent, he made a Law,
To keep her ſtill, and men in awe,
That who ſo askt her for his wife,
His riddle told not, loſt his life:
So for her many a wight did die,
As yon grim looks do teſtifie.
What now enſues to the judgment of your eye,
I give my cauſe, who beſt can teſtifie.

scene.stagedir: Enter Antiochus, Prince Pericles, and followers.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Young Prince of Tyre, you have at large receiv'd
The danger of the task you undertake.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I have (Antiochus) and with a ſoul emboldned
With the glory of her praiſe, think death no hazard,
In this enterprize.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Bring in our daughter, cloathed like a bride
For embracements, even of Jove himſelf;
At whoſe conception, till Lucina reign'd,
Nature this dowry gave, to glad her preſence,
The Senate houſe of Planets all did ſit,
To knit in her their beſt perfeƈtions.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: See where ſhe comes, apparell'd like the Spring,
Graces her subjeƈts, and her thoughts the King,
Of every vertue gives renown to men:
Her face the book of praiſes, where is read.
Nothing but curious pleaſures as from thence,
Sorrow were ever rackt, and teſty wrath
Could never be her mild companion.
You gods that made me man, and ſway in love,
That have inflam'd deſire in my breſt,
To taſte the fruite of yon celeſtiall tree,
(Or die in the adventure)be my helpes,
As I am ſonne and ſervant to your will,
To compaſſe ſuch a bondleſſe happineſſe.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Prince Pericles.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: That would be ſonne to great Antiochus.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Before thee ſtands this faire Hesperides,
With golden fruite, but dangerous to be toucht:
For death like Dragons here affright thee hard?
Her face like heaven enticeth thee to view
Her countleſſe glory, which deſert muſt gaine:
And which without deſert, becauſe thine eye
Preſumes to reach, all the whole heape muſt dye,
Yon ſometimes famous Princes like thy ſelfe
Drawn by report, adventurous by deſire,
Tell thee with ſpeechleſſe tongues, and ſemblance pale,
That without covering ſave yon field of ſtarres,
Here they ſtand martyrs ſlaine in Cupids warres:
And with dead cheeks adviſe thee to deſiſt,
For going on deaths net, whom none reſiſt.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Antiochus I thank thee, who hath taught
My frail mortality to know it ſelfe,
And by thoſe fearefull obieƈts to prepare
This body, like to them, to what I muſt:
For death remembred, ſhould be like a Myrrour,
Who tels us, life’s but breath, to truſt in error:
Ile make my will then, and as ſicke men do,
Who know the world, ſee heaven, but feeling wœ,
Gripe not at earthly ioyes, as erſt they did.
So I bequeath a happy peace to you
And all good men, as every prince ſhould do,
My riches to the earth from whence they came:
But my vnſpotted fire of Love to you,
Thus ready for the way of life or death,
I waite the ſharpeſt blow (Antiochus)
Scorning advice. Reade the concluſion then.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Which read and not expounded, tis decreed
As these before thou thy ſelfe ſhalt bleed.

speech.speaker: Daugh.
speech.line: Of all ſaid yet, thou prove proſperous,
Of all ſaid yet, I wiſh Thee happineſſe.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Like a bold champion I aſſume the liſtes,
Nor aske advice of any other thought,
But faithfulneſſe and courage.

line.recite: I am no Viper, yet I feed
On mothers fleſh which did me breed:
I ſought a huſband, in which labour
I found that kindneſſe in a father.
Hee’s father, ſonne, and huſband milde,
I Mother, Wife, and yet his child.
How they may be, and yet in two,
As you will live, reſolve it you.

speech.line: Sharp phyſick is the laſt? but O you Powers!
That gives heaven countleſte eyes to view mens aƈtes
Why could they not their ſights perpetually?
If this be true, which makes me pale to read it,
Fair glaſſe of light, I loved you, and could ſtill,
Were not this glorious Casket ſtor’d with ill:
But I muſt tell you, now my thoughts revolt,
for he’s no man on whom perfeƈtions wait;
That knowing ſinne within, will touch the gate:
You are a fair Vyol, and your ſence the ſtrings,
Who finger’d to make man his lawfull muſick,
Would draw heaven down, and all the gods to hearken;
But being plaid upon before your time,
Hell only danceth at ſo harſh a chime:
Good ſooth I care not for you.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Prince Pericles, touch not upon thy life,
For that’s an Article within our Law,
As dangerous as the reſt: your times expir’d,
Either expound now, or receive your ſentence.

speech.speaker: Peri.
speech.line: Great King,
Few love to hear the ſins they love to aƈt,
’Twould braid your ſelf too near for me to tell it:
Who hath a book of all that Monarchs do,
He’s more ſecure to keep it ſhut, then ſhewn:
For vice repeated, is like the wandring wind,
Blows duſt in others eyes, to ſpread it ſelf;
And yet the end of all is bought thus dear,
The breath is gone, and the ſore eyes ſee clear.
To ſtop the aire would hurt them, the blind Mole caſt
Copt hills towards heaven, to tell the earth is throng’d
By mans oppreſſion, and the poor worme doth die for’t.
Kings are earths Gods: in vice their law’s their will,
And if Jove ſtray, who dares ſay, Jove doth ill.
It is enough you know it, and ’tis fit;
What being more known, grows worſe to ſmother it.
All love the womb that their Being bred,
Then give my tongue like leave to love my head.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Heaven that I had it; he has found the meaning,
But I will gloze with him. Young Prince of Tyre,
Though by the tenor of our ſtriƈt ediƈt,
Your expoſition miſ-interpreting,
We might proceed to cancel of your daies;
Yet hope, ſucceeding from ſo fair a tree,
As your fair ſelf, doth tune us otherwiſe:
Forty daies longer we do reſpite you,
If by which time our ſecret be undone,
This mercy ſhews, we’ll joy in ſuch a ſon:
And untill then, your entertain ſhall be
As doth befit our honour, and your worth.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: How curteſie would ſeem to cover ſin,
When what is done is like an hypocrite,
The which is good in nothing but in ſight,
If it be true that I interpret falſe,
Then were it certain you were not ſo bad,
As with foul Inceſt to abuſe your ſoul:
Where now you’r both a father and a ſon,
By your untimely claſpings with your child,
(Which pleaſures fits a husband, not a father)
And ſhe an eater of her mothers fleſh,
By the defiling of her parents bed,
And both like ſerpents are, who though they feed
On ſweeteſt flowers, yet they poiſon breed.
Antioch farewell, for wiſdome ſees, thoſe men
Bluſh not in aƈtions blacker then the night,
Will ſhew no courſe to keep them from the light:
One ſin (I know) another doth provoke;
Murder’s as near to luſt, as flame to ſmoak.
Poyſon and treaſon are the hands of ſin,
I, and the Targets to put off the ſhame;
Then leaſt my life be cropt to keep you clear,
By flight I’le ſhun the danger which I fear.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: He hath found the meaning,
For which we mean to have his head,
He muſt not live to trumpet forth my infamy,
Nor tell the world Antiochus doth ſinne
In ſuch a loathed manner.
And therefore inſtantly this Prince muſt die,
For by his fall my honour muſt keep high.
Who attends us there?

speech.speaker: Thal.
speech.line: Doth your Highneſſe call?

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Thaliard, you are of our Chamber,
And our mind pertakes her private aƈtions
To your ſecreſie; and for your faithfulneſs
We will advance you, Thaliard.
Behold, here’s poiſon and here’s gold,
We hate the Prince of Tyre, and thou muſt kill him.
It fits thee not to ask the reaſon why:
Becauſe we bid it: ſay, is it done?

speech.speaker: Thal.
speech.line: My Lord, ’tis done.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Enough. Let your breath cool your ſelf, telling
your haſte.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: My Lord, Prince Pericles is fled.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: As thou wilt live, flye after; and as an arrow
ſhot from a well experient Archer, hits the mark his eye
doth level at: ſo thou never return, unleſs thou ſay,
Prince Pericles is dead.

speech.speaker: Tha
speech.line: My Lord, if I can get him within my piſtols length,
I’le make him ſure enough: ſo farewell to your Highneſs.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Thaliard adieu, till Pericles be dead,
My heart can lend no ſuccour to my head.

scene.stagedir: Enter Pericles, Hellicanus, with his Lords.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Let none diſturb us:
Why ſhould this change of thoughts,
The ſad companion dull-ey’d melancholly,
By me ſo us’d a gueſt as not an hour,
In the dayes glorious walk or peacefull night,
The tombe where grief ſhould ſleep, can breed me quiet,
Here pleaſures court mine eyes, and mine eyes ſhun them,
And danger which I fear’d, is at Antioch,
Whoſe arme ſeems far too ſhort to hit me here,
Yet neither pleaſures art can joy my ſpirits,
Nor yet the others diſtance comfort me:
Then it is thus, the paſſions of the mind,
That have their firſt conception by miſ-dread,
Have after nouriſhment and life by care;
And what was firſt but fear, what might be done,
Grows elder now, and cares it be not done.
And ſo ’tis with me, the great Antiochus,
’Gainſt whom I am too little to contend,
Since he’s ſo great, can make his will his aƈt,
Will think me ſpeaking, though I ſwear to ſilence,
Nor boots it me to ſay I honour,
If he ſuſpeƈt I may diſhonor him.
And what may make him bluſh in being known,
He’ll ſtop the courſe by which it might be known,
With hoſtile forces he’ll ore-ſpread the Land,
And with the ſtint of war will look ſo huge,
Amazement ſhall drive courage from the ſtate:
Our men be vanquiſh’d, ere they do reſiſt,
And ſubjeƈts puniſht, that never thought offence,
Which care of them, not pitty of my ſelf,
Who once no more but as the tops of trees,
Which fence the roots they grow by, and defend them,
Make both my body pine, and ſoul to languiſh,
And puniſh that before that he would puniſh.

speech.speaker: 1. Lord.
speech.line: Joy and all comfort in your ſacred breaſt.

speech.speaker: 2. Lord.
speech.line: And keep your mind till ye return to us
peacefull and comfortable.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Peace, peace, and give experience tongue:
They do abuſe the King that flatter him,
For flattery is the bellows blows up ſin,
The thing the which is flattered, but a ſpark,
To which that ſpark gives heart and ſtronger glowing;
Whereas reproof obedient and in order,
Fits Kings as they are men, for they may erre,
When Signior Sooth here doth proclaim peace,
He flatters you, makes war upon your life.
Prince, pardon me, or ſtrike me if you pleaſe,
I cannot be much lower than my knees.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: All leave us elſe: but let your cares ore-look
What ſhipping, and what ladings in our Haven,
And then return to us: Hellicanus thou haſt
Moov’d us: what ſeeſt thou in our looks:

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: An angry brow, dread Lord.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: If there be ſuch a dart in Princes frowns,
How durſt thy tongue move anger to our face?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: How dares the planets look up unto heaven,
From whence they have their nouriſhment?

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Thou know’ſt I have power to take thy life from thee

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: I have ground the axe my ſelf,
Do but you ſtrike the blow.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Riſe, prithee riſe, ſit down, thou art no flatterer,
I thank thee for it, and heaven forbid,
That Kings ſhould let their ears hear their faults hid.
Fit Councellor, and ſervant for a Prince,
Who by thy wiſdome makes a Prince thy servant,
What would’ſt thou have me do:

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: To bear with patience ſuch griefs,
As you your ſelf do lay upon your ſelf.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Thou ſpeak’ſt like a Physitian, Helicanus,
That miniſter’s a potion unto me,
That thou would’ſt tremble to receive thy ſelf.
Attend me then; I went to Antioch,
Whereas thou know’ſt (againſt the face of death)
I ſought the purchaſe of a glorious beauty,
From whence an iſſue I might propigate,
Are armes to Princes, and bring joyes to Subjeƈts.
Her face was to mine eye beyond all wonder,
The reſt (hark in thine ear) as black as inceſt,
Which by my knowledge found, the ſinfull father,
Seem’d not to ſtrike, but ſmooth: But thou know’ſt this,
’Tis time to fear, when tyrants ſeem to kiſs.
Which fear ſo grew in me, I hither fled,
Under the covering of a carefull night,
Who ſeem’d my good Proteƈtor: and being here,
Bethought what was paſt, what might ſucceed;
I knew him tyrannous, and tyrants fear
Decreaſe not, but grow faſter then the years:
And ſhould he think, as no doubt he doth,
That I ſhould open to the liſtening air,
How many worthy Princes bloud were ſhed,
To keep his bed of blackneſs unlaid ope,
To lop that doubt, he’ll fill this Land with armes,
And make pretence of wrong that I have done him,
When all for mine, if I may call offence,
Muſt feel warrs blow, who fears not innocence:
Which love to all, of which thy ſelf art one,
Who now reproved’ſt me for it.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Alas, ſir.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Drew ſleep out of mine eyes, bloud from my cheeks,
Muſings into my mind, with a thouſand doubts
How I might ſtop this tempeſt ere it came,
And finding little comfort to relieve them,
I thought it princely charity to grieve for them.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Well, my Lord, ſince you have given me leave to ſpeak,
Freely will I ſpeak. Antiochus you fear,
And juſtly too I think you fear the tyrant,
Who either by publick war or private treaſon,
Will take away your life: therefore, my Lord, go travel
for a while, till that his rage and anger be forgot; or till
the Deſtinies do cut his thread of life: your Rule di-
reƈt to any, if unto me, day ſerves not light more faith-
full then I’le be.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I do not doubt thy faith,
But ſhould he wrong my liberties in my abſence?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: We’ll mingle our blouds together in the earth,
From whence we had our being, and our birth.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Tyre, I now look from thee then, and to Tharſus
Intend my travel, where I’le hear from thee;
And by whoſe Letters I’le diſpoſe my ſelf,
The care I had and have of Subjeƈts good,
On thee I lay, whoſe wiſdomes ſtrength can bear it,
I’le take thy word for faith, not ask thine oath,
Who ſhuns not to break one, will ſure crack them both:
But in our orbes we live ſo round and ſafe,
That time of both this truth ſhall nere convince,
Thou ſheweſt a ſubjeƈts ſhine, I a true Prince.

speech.speaker: Thal.
speech.line: So, this is Tyre, and this the Court, here muſt
I kill King Pericles, and if I do it not, I am ſure to be
hang’d at home: it is dangerous.
Well, I perceive he was a wiſe fellow, and had good
diſcretion that, being bid to ask what he would of the
King, deſired he might know none of his ſecrets. Now do
I ſee he had ſome reaſon for it: for if a King bid a man
be a villain, he is bound by the indenture of his oath to be
one.
Huſht, here comes the Lords of Tyre.

scene.stagedir: Enter Helicanus, Eſcanes, with other Lords of Tyre.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: You ſhall not need my fellow-Peers of Tyre,
further to queſtion me of your Kings departure. His ſeal-
ed Commiſſion left in truſt with me, doth ſpeak ſuffi-
ciently, he’s gone to travel.

speech.speaker: Thal.
speech.line: How the King gone?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: If further yet you will be ſatisfied, why (as it
were unlicenc’d of your loves) he would depart? I’le give
ſome light unto you: Being at Antioch.

speech.speaker: Thal.
speech.line: What from Antioch?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Royal Antiochus (on what cauſe I know not)
took ſome diſpleaſure at him, at leaſt he judged ſo: and
doubting that he had erred or ſinned, to ſhew his ſorrow,
he would correƈt himſelf; ſo puts himſelf unto the ſhip-
mans toyl, with whom each minute threatens life or death.

speech.speaker: Thal.
speech.line: Well, I perceive I ſhall not be hanged now,
I shall not be hang’d now, although I would;
although I would; but ſince he’s gone, the Kings Seas
muſt pleaſe: he ſcapte the Land, to periſh at the Sea: I’le
preſent my ſelf, Peace to the Lords of Tyre.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Lord Thaliard from Antiochus is welcome.

speech.speaker: Thal.
speech.line: From him I come with meſſage unto Princely
Pericles; but ſince my landing I have underſtood, your
Lord hath betook himſelf to unknown travels, my meſ-
ſage muſt return from whence it came.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: We have no reaſon to deſire it, commended to
our Maſter, not to us; yet ere you ſhall depart, this we de-
ſire as friends to Antioch, we may feaſt in Tyre.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cleon the Governor of Tharſus, with his wife and others.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: My Dioniſia, ſhall we reſt us here,
And by relating tales of others griefs,
See if ’twill teach us to forget our own?

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: That were to blow at fire in hope to quench it,
For who digs hills becauſe they do aſpire,
Throws down one Mountain to caſt up a higher:
O my diſtreſſed Lord, even ſuch our griefs are,
Here they are but felt, and ſeen with miſchief’s eyes,
But like to groves being topt, they higher riſe.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: O Dioniſia,
Who wanteth food, and will not ſay he wants it,
Or can conceal his hunger till he famiſh?
Our tongues and ſorrowes do ſound deep:
Our wœs into the air, our eyes to weep,
Till tongues fetch breath that may proclaim
Them louder, that if heaven ſlumber, while
Their creatures want, they may awake
Their helpers, to comfort them.
I’le then diſcourſe our wœs felt ſeveral years,
And wanting breath to speak, help me with tears.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: I’le do my beſt, ſir.

speech.speaker: Cle.
speech.line: This Tharſus, ore which I have the government,
A City, on whom plenty held full hand;
For riches ſtrew’d her ſelf even in the ſtreets,
Whoſe towers bore heads ſo high, they kiſt the clouds,
And ſtrangers nere beheld, but wondr’d at,
Whoſe men and dames ſo jetted and adorn’d,
Like one anothers glaſſe to trim them by:
Their tables were ſtor’d full, to glad the ſight,
And not ſo much to feed on, as delight,
All poverty was corn’d and pride ſo great,
The name of help grew odious to repeat.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Oh ’tis true.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: But ſee what heaven can do by this our change:
Theſe mouths, who but of late, earth, ſea, and ayre,
Were all too little to content and pleaſe,
Although they gave their creatures in abundance:
As houſes are defil’d for want of uſe,
They are now ſtarv’d for want of exerciſe;
Thoſe pallats, who, not yet two ſavers younger,
Muſt have inventions to delight the taſte,
Would now be glad of bread, and beg for it:
Theſe mothers who to nouzle up their babes,
Thought nought too curious, are ready now
To eat thoſe little darlings whom they loved,
So ſharp are hungers teeth, that man and wife,
Draw lots who firſt ſhall die to lengthen life.
Here ſtands a Lord, and there a Lady weeping,
Here many ſink, yet thoſe which ſee them fall,
Have ſcarce ſtrength left to give them burial.
Is not this true?

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Our cheeks and hollow eyes do witneſſe it.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: O let thoſe Cities that of plenties cup,
And her proſperities ſo largely taſte,
With their ſuperfluous ryots hear theſe tears,
The miſery of Tharſus may be theirs.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Where’s the Lord Governor?

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: Here, ſpeak out they ſorrows, which thou bring’ſt
in haſte, for comfort is too far for us to expeƈt.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: We have deſcried upon our neighbouring ſhore,
A portly ſail of ſhips make hitherward.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: I thought as much.
One ſorrow never comes but brings an heir,
That may ſucceed as his inheritour:
And ſo in ours; ſome neighbouring Nation,
Taking advantage of our miſery,
That ſtuft the hollow veſſels with their power,
To beat us down, the which are down already,
And make a conqueſt of unhappy me,
Whereas no glory got to overcome.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: That’s the leaſt fear.
For by the ſemblance of their white flags diſplaid, they bring
us peace, and come to us as favourers, not as fœs.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: Thou ſpeak’ſt like hymnes untuter’d to repeat,
Who makes the faireſt ſhew, means moſt deceit.
But bring they what they will, and what they can,
What need we fear, the ground’s the loweſt,
And we are half way there: Go tell their General we at-
tend him here, to know for what he comes, and whence
he comes, and what he craves.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: I go, my lord.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: Welcome is peace, if he on peace conſiſt;
If warrs, we are unable to reſiſt.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Lord Governor, for ſo we hear you are,
Let not our ſhips and number of our men
Be like a Beacon fired, to amaze your eyes,
We have heard your miſeries as far as Tyre,
And ſeen the deſolation of your ſtreets;
Nor come we to adde ſorrow to your tears,
But to releaſe them of their heavy load,
And theſe our ſhips, you happily may think
Are like the Trojan horſe, was ſtuft within
With bloody veins expeƈting overthrow,
Are ſtor’d with corn, to make your needy bread,
And give them life, whom hunger ſtarv’d half dead.

speech.speaker: Omnes.
speech.line: The gods of Greece proteƈt you,
And we’ll pray for you.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Ariſe, I pray you, ariſe; we do not look for reve-
rence, but for love, and harbourage for our ſelf, our ſhips,
and men.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: The which when any ſhall not gratifie,
Or pay you with unthankfulneſſe in thought,
Be it our wives, our children, or our ſelves,
The curſe of heaven and men ſucceed their evils:
Till when, the which (I hope) ſhall ne’re be ſeen,
Your Grace is welcome to our Town and us.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Which welcome we’ll accept, feaſt here a while,
Untill our ſtars that frown, lend us a ſmile.

speech.speaker: Gower.

line.italic: Here have you ſeen a mighty King
His child, I wis, to inceſt bring:
A better Prince and benigne Lord,
That will prove awfull both in deed and word.
Be quiet then, as men ſhould be,
Till he hath paſt neceſſity:
I’le ſhew you thoſe in troubles reigne,
Looſing a myte, a Mountain gain:
The good in converſation,
To whom I give my benizon.

speech.line: Is ſtill at Tharſus, where each man

line.italic: Thinks all is writ he ſpoken can:
And to remember what he dœs,
Build his Statue to make him glorious:
But tydings to the contrary,
Are brought t’your eyes, what need ſpeak I.

speech.stagedir: Enter at one door Pericles talking with Cleon, all the Train with them. Enter at another door, a Gentleman with a letter to Pericles; Pericles ſhews the letter to Cleon, Pericles gives the Meſſenger a reward, and Knights him.
Exit Pericles at one door, and Cleon at another.
speech.line: Good Hellican that ſtaid at home,

line.italic: Not to eat hony like a Drone,
From others labours; for though he ſtrive
To killen bad, keep good alive:
And to fulfill his Princes deſire,

speech.line: Sav’d one of all that haps in Tyre:
How Thaliard came full bent with ſin,

line.italic: And had intent to murder him;

speech.line: And that in Tharſus was not beſt,

line.italic: Longer for him to make his reſt:
He doing ſo, put forth to Seas,
Where when men bin, there’s ſeldom eaſe,
For now the wind begins to blow,
Thunder above, and deeps below,
Makes ſuch unquiet, that the ſhip
Should houſe him ſafe, is wrackt and ſplit,
And he (good Prince) having all loſt,
By waves, from coaſt to coaſtis toſt:
All periſhen of man, of pelf,
Ne ought eſcapen’d but himſelf;
Till fortune tired with doing bad,
Threw him aſhore to give him glad:
And here he comes; what ſhall be next,

speech.line: Pardon old Gower,thus long’s the Text.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Yet ceaſe your ire, you angry Stars of heaven,
Wind, Rain, and Thunder: Remember earthly man
Is but a ſubſtance that muſt yield to you:
And I (as fits my nature) do obey you.
Alas, the Seas hath caſt me on the Rocks,
Waſht me from ſhore to ſhore, and left my breath
Nothing to think on, but enſuing death:
Let it ſuffice the greatneſſe of your powers,
To have bereft a Prince of all his fortunes,
And having thrown him from your watry grave,
Here to have death in peace, is all he’ll crave.
What, to pelch?
Ha, come and bring away the Nets.
What patch-breech, I ſay.
What ſay you, Maſter?
Look how thou ſtirreſt now.
Come away, or I’le fetch thee with a wannion.
Faith Maſter, I am thinking of the poor men
That were caſt away before us, even now.
Alas poor ſouls, it grieved my heart to hear
What pittifull cries they made to us, to help them,
When (welladay) we could ſcarcely help our ſelves.
Nay Maſter, ſaid not I as much,
When I ſaw the Porpas how he bounſt and tumbled?
They ſay, they are half fiſh, half fleſh:
A plague on them, they ne’re come but I look to be waſht.
Maſter, I marvel how the fiſhes live in the Sea?
Why as men do a Land,
The great ones eat up the little ones:
I can compare our rich Miſers, to nothing ſo fitly
As to a Whale; he plaies and tumbles,
Driving the poor Fry before him,
And at laſt devour them all at a mouthfull.
Such Whales have I heard on a’th land,
Who never leave gaping, till they ſwallowed
The whole Pariſh, Church, Steeple, Bells and all.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: A pretty moral.
But Maſter, if I had been the Sexton,
I would have been that day in the Belfrey.
Why man?
Becauſe he ſhould have ſwallowed me too,
And when I had been in his belly,
I would have kept ſuch a jangling of the bells,
That he ſhould never have left
Till he caſſt Bells, Steeple, Church and Pariſh up again:
But if the good King Simonides were of my mind,
We would purge the Land of theſe Drones,
That rob the Bee of her honny.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: How from the fenny ſubjeƈt of the ſea
Theſe fiſhers tell the infirmities of men,
And from their watry Empire recolleƈt
All that may men approve, or men deteƈt.
Peace be at your labour, honeſt fiſhermen.
Honeſt, good fellow, what’s that, if it be a day fits you,
Search out of the Kalender, and no body look after it?

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Y’may ſee the ſea hath caſt me upon your coaſt.
What a drunken knave was the ſea,
To caſt thee in our way.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: A man whom both the waters and the wind,
In that vaſt Tennis-Court, hath made the Ball
For them to play upon, entreats you pitty him:
He asks of you, that never us’d to beg.
No friend, cannot you beg?
Here’s them in our Country of Greece,
Gets more with begging, then we can do with working.
Canſt thou catch any Fiſhes then?

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I never praƈtis’d it.
Nay then thou wilt ſtarve ſure; for here’s nothing
to be got now-a-daies unleſſe thou canſt fiſh for’t.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: What I have been, I have forgot to know;
But what I am, want teaches me to think on:
A man throng’d up with cold, my veins are chill,
And have no more of life, then may ſuffice
To give my tongue that heat to ask your help:
Which if you ſhall refuſe, when I am dead,
For that I am a man, pray ſee me buried.
Die ke-tha, now gods forbid, I have a gown here,
come put it on, keep thee warme: now afore me a hand-
ſome fellow: Come, thou ſhalt go home, and we’ll have
fleſh for all day, fiſh for faſting dayes and more; or Pud-
dings and Flap-jacks, and thou ſhalt be welcome.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I thank you, ſir.
Hark you, my friend, You said you could not beg.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I did but crave.
But crave? Then I’le turn craver too,
And ſo I ſhall ſcape whipping.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Why, are your beggers whipt then?
Oh not all, my friend, not all: for if all your beg-
gers were whipt. I would wiſh no better office, then to be
Beadle. But Maſter, I’le go draw the Net.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: How well this honeſt mirth becomes their labour?
Hark you, ſir, do you know where ye are?

speech.speaker: PerR.
speech.line: Not well.
I tell you, this is called Pantapolis,
And our King, the good Symonides.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: The good King Symonides, do you call him:
I ſir, and he deſerves ſo to be call’d,
For his peaceable reigne, and good government.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: He is a happy King, ſince he gains from
His Subjeƈts, the name of good, by his government.
How far is his Court diſtant from this ſhore?
Marry, ſir, half a daies journey: and I’le tell you, he
hath a fair daughter, and to morrow is her birth-day, and
there are Princes and Knights come from all parts of the
world, to Juſt and Turney for her love.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Were my fortunes equal to my deſires,
I could wiſh to make one there.
O ſir, things muſt be as they may: and what a man
Cannot get, he may lawfully deal for his wives ſoul.

scene.stagedir: Enter the two other Fiſher-men, drawing up a Net.

speech.line: Help, Maſter, help, here’s a fiſh hangs in the Net, like
a poor mans right in the law, ’twill hardly come out. Ha
bots on’t, ’tis come at laſt, and ’tis turned to a ruſty Armor.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: An Armor, friends, I pray you let me ſee it.
Thanks Fortune, yet that after all croſſes,
Thou giveſt me ſomewhat to repair my ſelf:
And though it was mine own part of my heritage,
Which my dead father did bequeath to me,
With this ſtriƈt charge, even as he left his life:
Keep it, my Pericles, it hath been a ſhield
’Twixt me and death; and pointed to this Brayſe:
For that it ſaved me; keep it in like neceſſity:
The which the gods proteƈt thee, Fame may defend thee.
It kept where I kept, I ſo dearly loved it,
Till the rough Seas (that ſpares not any man)
Took it in rage, though calm’d have given’t again:
I thank thee for’t my shipwrack now’s no ill,
Since I have here my father gave in’s will.
What mean you, ſir?

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: To beg of you (kind friends) this coat of worth,
For it was ſometime Target to a King,
I know it by this mark: he loved me dearly,
And for his ſake, I wiſh the having of it:
And that you’d guide me to your Soveraigns Court,
Where with it I may appear a Gentleman:
And if that ever my low fortune’s better,
I’le pay your bounties; till then reſt your debter.
Why, wilt thou turney for the Lady?

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I’le ſhew the vertue I have born in Armes.
Why take it, and the gods give thee good an’t.
But hark you, my friend, ’twas we that made up this
garment through the rough ſeams of the waters: there are
certain condolements, certain vails; I hope, ſir, if you
thrive, you’ll remember from whence you had them.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Believe it I will:
By your furtherance I am cloathed in Steel,
And ſpight of all the rupture of the ſea,
This Jewell holds his building on my arme:
Unto thy value I will mount my ſelf.
Upon a Courſer, whoſe delightfull ſteps,
Shall make the gazer joy to ſee him tread;
Only (my friend) I yet am unprovided of a payre of Baſes.
We’ll ſure provide, thou ſhalt have
My beſt gown to make thee a pair;
And I’le bring thee to the Court my ſelf.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Then honour be but a Goal to my will,
This day I’le riſe, or elſe adde ill to ill.
Are the Knights ready to begin the Triumph?

speech.speaker: 1. Lord.
speech.line: They are, my Liege, and ſtay your comming,
To preſent themſelves.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Return them; we are ready, and our Daughter here,
In honour of whoſe birth. theſe triumphs are,
Sits here like beauties child, whom Nature gat,
For men to ſee, and ſeeing wonder at.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: It pleaſeth you (my royall father) to expreſſe
My commendations great, whoſe merit’s leſſe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: It’s fit it ſhould be ſo; for Princes are
A modell which heaven makes like it ſelf:
As Jewels loſe their glory, if negleƈted,
So Princes their Renownes, if not reſpeƈted.
’Tis now your honor (Daughter) to entertain
The labour of each Knight, in his device.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: Which to preſerve mine honour, I’le perform.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Who is the firſt, that doth preferre himſelf?

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: A Knight of Sparta (my renowned Father)
And the device he bears upon his ſhield,
Is a black Æthiope reaching at the Sun;
The word; Lux tua vita mihi.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: He loves you well, that holds his life of you.
Who is the ſecond, that preſents himſelf?

speech.speaker: Tha.
speech.line: A Prince of Macedon (my royall Father)
And the device he bears upon his Shield,
Is an armed Knight, that’s conquer’d by a Lady.
The Motto thus in Spaniſh: Pue Per dolecra kee per forſa.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And what’s the third?

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: The third of Antioch; and his device
A wreathe of Chivalry: the word, Me Pompey provexit apex.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What is the fourth?

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: A burning Torch that’s turn’d upſide down;
The word, Qui me alit me extinguit.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Which ſhewes that beauty hath his power and will,
Which can as well enflame, as it can kill.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: The fifth, an hand environed with clouds,
Holding out gold, that’s by the touch-ſtone tri’d:
The Motto thus: Sic ſpeƈtanda fides.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And what’s the ſixth and laſt, the which the
Knight himſelf with ſuch a gracefull courteſie deliverd?

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: He ſeems to be a ſtranger: but his Preſent is
A withered Branch, that’s onely green at top;
The Motto, In hac ſpe vivo.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: A pretty morall; from the dejeƈted ſtate
wherein he is, he hopes by you his fortunes yet may
flouriſh.

speech.speaker: 1. Lord.
speech.line: He had need mean better than his outward
ſhew can any way ſpeak in his juſt commend: For by
his ruſty out-ſide, he appeares to have praƈtiſed more the
Whipſtock, then the Lance.

speech.speaker: 2. Lord.
speech.line: He well may be a ſtranger, for he comes to
an honour’d triumph ſtrangely furniſht.

speech.speaker: 3. Lord.
speech.line: And on ſet purpoſe let his armour ruſt
Untill this day, to ſcowre it in the duſt.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Opinion’s but a foole, that makes us ſcan
The outward habit by the inward man.
But ſtay, the Knights are comming,
We will withdraw into the Gallery.

scene.stagedir: Great ſhouts, and all cry, the mean Knight.
Enter the King and Knights from Tilting.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Knights, to ſay you’re welcome, were ſuperfluous.
I place upon the volume of your deeds,
As in a Title page, your worth in armes,
Were more then you expeƈt, or more then’s ſir,
Since every worth in ſhew commends it ſelf:
Prepare for mirth, for mirth comes at a feaſt.
You are Princes, and my gueſts.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: But you, my Knight and gueſt,
To whom this wreathe of viƈtory I give,
And Crown you King of this dayes happineſſe.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: ’Tis more by fortune (Lady) then my merit.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Call it by what you will, the day is yours,
And here, I hope, is none that envies it:
In framing an Artiſt, art hath thus decreed,
To make ſome good, but others to exceed,
And you her labour’d Schollar: come, Queen oth’Feaſt,
For (Daughter) ſo you are, here take your place:
Martiall the reſt, as they deſerve their grace.

speech.speaker: Knights.
speech.line: We are honoured much by good Symonides.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Your preſence glads our dayes, honour we love,
For who hates honour, hates the gods above.

speech.speaker: Marſ.
speech.line: Sir, yonder is your place.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Some other is more fit.

speech.speaker: 1. Knight.
speech.line: Contend not, ſir, for we are Gentlemen,
That neither in our hearts, nor outward eyes
Envy the great, nor dœ the low deſpiſe.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: You are right courteous Knights.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Sit, ſir, ſit.
By Jove (I wonder) that is King of thoughts,
Theſe Cates reſiſt me, he not thought upon.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: By Juno (that is Queen of Marriage)
All Viands that I eat dœ ſeem unſavoury,
Wiſhing him my meat: ſure he’s a gallant Gentleman.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: He’s but a country gentleman: has done no more
Then other Knights have done, has broken ſtaffe,
Or ſo; let it paſſe.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: To me he ſeems like Diamond to Glaſſe.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Yon King’s to me, like to my Father’s piƈture,
Which tells me in that glory once he was,
And Princes ſat like ſtarres about his Throne,
And he the Sun, for them to reverence;
None that beheld him, but like leſſer lights,
Did vaile their Crowns to his ſupreamacy;
Where now his Son, like a Glo-worm in the night,
The which hath fire in darkneſſe none in light:
Whereby I ſee that Time’s the King of men,
For he’s their Parents, and he is their grave,
And gives them what he will, not what they crave.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What, are you merry, Knights?

speech.speaker: Knights.
speech.line: Who can be other in this royall preſence?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Here, with a cup that’s stirr’d unto the brimme,
As you dœ love, fill to your Miſtreſſe lips,
We drink this health to you.

speech.speaker: Knights.
speech.line: We thank your Grace.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Yet pawſe a while; yon Knight doth ſit too melancholly,
As if the entertainment in our Court,
Had not a ſhew might countervaile his worth:
Note it not you, Thaiſa;

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: What is’t to me, my Father?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: O, attend, my Daughter,
Princes in this, ſhould live like gods above,
Who freely give to every one that come to honour them:
And Princes not doing ſo, are like to Gnats,
Which make a ſound, but kill’d, are wondred at:
Therefore to make his entrance more ſweet,
Here, ſay we drink this standing bowle of wine to him.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: Alaſſe, my Father, it befits not me,
Unto a ſtranger Knight to be ſo bold,
He may my proffer take for an offence,
Since men take womens gifts for impudence.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: How? dœ as I bid you, or you’ll move me elſe.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: Now by the gods, he could not pleaſe me better.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And furthermore tell him, we deſire to know of him,
Of whence he is, his name and Parentage.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: The King my Father (ſir) has drunk to you.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I thank him.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: Wiſhing it ſo much blood unto your life.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I thank both him and you, and pledge him freely.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: And further, he deſires to know of you,
Of whence you are, your name and parentage.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: A gentleman of Tyre, my name Pericles,
My education been in Arts and Armes.
Who looking for adventures in the world,
Was by the rough Seas reft of ſhips and men,
And after ſhip-wrack, driven upon this ſhore.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: He thanks your Grace; names himſelf Pericles,
A Gentleman of Tyre, who only by misfortune of the ſeas,
Bereft of ſhips and men, caſt on the ſhore.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now by the gods, I pitty his misfortune,
And will awake him from his melancholly.
Come, Gentlemen, we sit too long on trifles,
And waſte the time, which looks for other revels.
Even in your armours as you are addreſt,
Will very well become a Souldiers dance:
I will not have excuſe, with ſaying that
Loud Muſick is too harſh for Ladies heads,
Since they love men in Armes, as well as beds.
So, this was well ask’d, ’twas so well perform’d.
Come, ſir, here’s a Lady that wants breathing too:
And I have heard, you Knights of Tyre
Are excellent in making Ladies trip,
And that their meaſures are as excellent.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: In thoſe that praƈtiſe them, they are (my Lord.)

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Oh that’s as much, as you would be deny’d
Of your fair courteſie: unclaſpe, unclaſpe.
Thanks, Gentlemen, to all; all have done well,
But you the beſt: Pages and lights, to conduƈt
Theſe Knights unto their ſeverall Lodgings:
Yours, ſir, we have given order to be next our own.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I am at your Graces pleaſure.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Princes, it is too late to talk of love,
And that’s the marke I know you levell at:
Therefore each one betake him to his reſt,
To morrow, all for ſpeeding dœ their beſt.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: No, Eſcanes, know this of me,
Antiochus from inceſt liv’d not free:
For which, the moſt high gods not minding
Longer to with-hold the vengeance that
They had in ſtore, due to this hainous
Capitall offence; even in the height and pride
Of all his glory, when he was ſeated in
A Chariot of an ineſtimable value, and his Daughter
With him; a fire from heaven came and ſhrivel’d
Up thoſe bodies, even to loathing, for they ſo ſtunk,
That all thoſe eyes ador’d them, ere their fall,
Scorn now their hand ſhould give them buriall.

speech.speaker: Eſcanes.
speech.line: It was very ſtrange.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: And yet but juſtice; for though this King were great,
His greatneſſe was no guard to barre heavens ſhaft.
By ſin had his reward.

speech.speaker: Eſcan.
speech.line: ’Tis very true.

speech.speaker: 1. Lord.
speech.line: See, not a man in private conference,
Or counſell, hath reſpeƈt with him but he.

speech.speaker: 2. Lord.
speech.line: It ſhall no longer grieve without reproof.

speech.speaker: 3. Lord.
speech.line: And curſt be he that will not ſecond it.

speech.speaker: 1. Lord.
speech.line: Follow me then: Lord Hellicane, a word.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: With me? and welcome, happy day, my Lords.

speech.speaker: 1. Lord.
speech.line: Know that our griefs are riſen to the top,
And now at length they over-flow their banks.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Your griefs, for what?
Wrong not your Prince you love.

speech.speaker: 1. Lord.
speech.line: Wrong not your ſelf then, noble Hellican,
But if the Prince dœ live, let us ſalute him,
Or know what ground’s made happy by his breath:
If in the world he live, we’ll ſeek him out:
If in his grave he reſt, we’ll find him there,
And be reſolv’d, he lives to govern us:
Or dead, give’s cauſe to mourn his Funerall,
And leave us to our free Eleƈtion.

speech.speaker: 2. Lor.
speech.line: Whoſe death indeed, the ſtrongeſt in our cenſure,
And knowing this Kingdome is without a head,
Like goodly buildings left without a Roof,
Soon fall to ruine: your noble ſelf,
That beſt knowes how to rule, and how to reign,
We thus ſubmit unto our Soveraign.

speech.speaker: Omnes.
speech.line: Live, noble Hellican.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Try honours cauſe; forbear your ſuffrages:
If that you love Prince Pericles, forbear,
(Take I your wiſh, I leap into the Seas,
Where’s hourely trouble, for a minutes eaſe)
A twelve-moneth longer, let me entreat you
To forbear the abſence of your King;
If in which time expir’d he not return,
I ſhall with aged patience bear your yoke.
But if I cannot win you to this love,
Go ſearch like Nobles, like noble Subjeƈts,
And in your ſearch, ſpend your adventurous worth,
Whom if you finde, and winne unto return,
You ſhall like Diamonds ſit about his Crown.

speech.speaker: 1. Lord.
speech.line: To wiſedome, he’s a foole that will not yield,
And ſince Lord Hellican enjoyneth us,
We with our travels will endeavour.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Then you love us, we you, and we’ll claſp hands,
When Peeres thus knit, a Kingdome ever ſtands.

scene.stagedir: Enter the King reading of a Letter, at one door, and the Knights meet him.

speech.speaker: 1. Knight.
speech.line: Good morrow to the good Simonides.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Knights, from my Daughter this I let you know,
That for this twelve-moneth, ſhe’ll not undertake
A married life: her reaſon to her ſelf is onely known,
Which from her by no meanes can I get.

speech.speaker: 2. Knight.
speech.line: May we not get acceſſe to her (my Lord)

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Faith, by no meanes, ſhe hath ſo ſtriƈtly
Ti’d her to her Chamber, that ’tis impoſſible:
One twelve Moons more ſhe’ll wear Dianæs livery:
This by the eye of Cynthia hath ſhe vowed,
And on her virgin honor will not break.

speech.speaker: 3. Knight.
speech.line: Loath to bid farewell, we take our leaves.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: So, they are well diſpacht,
Now to my daughters Letter; ſhe tells me here,
She’ll wed the ſtranger Knight,
Or never more to view nor day nor light.
’Tis well, Miſtris, your choyce agrees with mine,
I like that well: nay how abſolute ſhe’s in’t,
Not minding whether I diſlike or no.
Well, I dœ commend her choyce, and will no longer
Have it be delayed: ſoft, here he comes,
I muſt diſſemble it.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: All fortune to the good Simonides.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: To you as much: Sir, I am beholding to you,
For your ſweet muſick this laſt night:
I dœ proteſt, my ears were never better fed
With ſuch delightfull pleaſing harmony.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: It is your Graces pleaſure to commend,
Not my deſert.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Sir, you are Muſicks maſter.

speech.speaker: Prt.
speech.line: The worſt of all her Schollars (my good Lord)

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Let me aske you one thing.
What dœ you think of my Daughter, ſir?

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: A moſt virtuous Princeſſe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And ſhe’s fair too, is ſhe not?

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: As a fair day in Summer: wondrous fair.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Sir, my Daughter thinks very well of you,
I, ſo well, that you muſt be her Maſter,
And ſhe will be your Schollar; therefore look to it.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I am unworthy for her Schoolmaſter.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: She thinks not ſo, peruſe this writing elſe.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: What’s here, a Letter, that ſhe loves the Knight of Tyre?
’Tis the King’s ſubtilty to have my life:
Oh ſeek not to intrap me, gracious Lord,
A ſtranger and diſtreſſed Gentleman,
That never aim’d ſo high to love your Daughter,
But bent all offices to honour her.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thou haſt bewitcht my Daughter,
And thou art a Villain.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: By the gods I have not; never did thought
Of mine levy offence; nor never did my aƈtions
Yet commence, a deed might gain her love,
Or your diſpleaſure.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Traitor, thou lyeſt.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Traitor!

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I, Traitor.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Even in his throat, unleſſe it be the King,
That calls me Traitor, I return the lye.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now by the gods I dœ applaud his courage.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: My aƈtions are as noble as my thoughts,
That never relliſht of a baſe deſcent:
I came unto the Court for honours cauſe,
And not be a Rebel to her ſtate:
And he that otherwiſe accounts of me,
This Sword ſhall prove, he’s honours enemy.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: No? here comes my Daughter, ſhe can witneſs it.

speech.speaker: PerR.
speech.line: Then as you are as virtuous, as fair,
Reſolve your angry Father, if my tongue
Did e’re ſolicite, or my hand ſubſribe
To any ſyllable that made love to you?

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: Why, ſir, if you had, who takes offence,
At that would make me glad?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Yea, miſtris, are you ſo peremptory?
I am glad of it withall my heart.
I’le tame you, I’le bring you in ſubjeƈtion.
Will you, not having my conſent,
Beſtow your love and your affeƈtions,
Upon a stranger? who, for ought I know,
May be (nor can I think the contrary)
As great in blood as I my ſelf.
Therefore hear you, Miſtreſſe, either frame
Your will to mine; and you, ſir, hear you,
Either be rul’d by me, or I’le make you—
Man and Wife; nay, come your hands
And lips muſt ſeale it too: and being joyn’d
I’le thus your hopes deſtroy, and for further grief,
God give you joy; what, are you both pleaſed?

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: Yes, if you love me, ſir.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Even as my life, or blood that foſters it.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What, are you both agreed?

speech.speaker: Amb.
speech.line: Yes, if it pleaſe your Majeſty.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: It pleaſeth me ſo well, that I will ſee you wed,
And then with what haſte you can, get you to bed.

line.italic: Now yſleep ſlaked hath the rout,
No din but ſnores the houſe.
Made louder by the ore-ſee beaſt,
Of this moſt pompous marriage feaſt:
The Cat with eyne of burning coale,
Now couches from the Mouſes hole;
And Cricket ſing at the Ovens mouth,
Are the blither for their drouth:

speech.line: Hymen hath brought the Bride to bed,

line.italic: Where by the loſſe of Maiden-head,
A babe is moulded, by attent,
And time that is ſo briefly ſpent,
With your fine fancies quaintly each,
What’s dumbe in ſhew, I’le plain with ſpeech.

speech.stagedir: Enter Pericles and Simonides at one door with attendants, a Meſſenger meets them, kneeles, and gives Pericles a Letter, Pericles ſhewes it Simonides, the Lords kneele to him; then enter Thaiſa with childe, with Lychorida a Nurſe, the King ſhewes her the Letter, ſhe rejoyces: ſhe and Pericles take leave of her Father, and depart.

line.italic: By many a dearne and painfull pearch

speech.line: Of Pericles, the carefull ſearch,

line.italic: By the four oppoſing Crignes,
Which the world together joynes,
Is made with all due diligence,
That horſe and ſaile, and high expence,

speech.line: Can ſteed the queſt at laſt from Tyre,

line.italic: Fame anſwering the moſt ſtrange enquire,

speech.line: To th’court of King Simonides

line.italic: Are Letters brought, the tenour theſe:

speech.line: Antiochus and his Daughter’s dead,
The men of Tyrus on the head
Of Hellicanus would ſet on
The Crown of Tyre, but he will none:

line.italic: The mutiny, he there haſtes t’oppreſſe,
Says to them, if King Pericles
Come not home in twice ſix Moones,
He, obedient to their doomes,
Will take the Crown: the ſumme of this,
Brought hither to Pentapolis,
Irony ſhed the Regions round,
And every one with claps can ſound,
Our heir apparant is a King:
Who dreamt? who thought of ſuch a thing?

speech.line: Brief, he muſt hence depart to Tyre,
His Queen, with child, makes her deſire;

line.italic: Which who ſhall croſſe along to go,
Omit we all their dole and wœ:

speech.line: Lychorida, her Nurſe ſhe takes,

line.italic: And ſo to Sea; then veſſell ſhakes,

speech.line: On Neptunes billow, half the flood,

line.italic: Hath their Keele cut: but fortune mov’d,
Varies again, the griſly North
Diſgorges ſuch a tempeſt forth,
That as a Duck for life that drives,
So up and down the poor ſhip dives:
The Lady ſhreeks, and well-a-near,
Doth fall in travell with her fear:
And what enſues in this ſelf ſtorme,
Shall for it ſelf, it ſelf perform:
I nill relate, aƈtion may
Conveniently the reſt convey;
Which might not? what by me is told,
In your imagination hold:
This Stage, the ſhip, upon whoſe Deck,

speech.line: The Seas toſt Pericles appeares to ſpeak.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: The God of this great vaſt, rebuke theſe ſurges
Which waſh both heaven and hell; and thou that haſt
Upon the windes command, bind them in Braſſe,
Having call’d them from the deep, O ſtill
Thy dearning dreadfull thunders; daily quench
Thy nimble ſulpherous flaſhes: O how, Lychorida?
How dœs my Queen? then ſtorm venomouſly,
Wilt thou ſpet all thy ſelf? the Seamans whiſtle
Is a whiſper in the eares of death,
Unheard Lychorida? Lucina, oh!
Divineſt Patroneſſe, and my Wife, gentle
To thoſe that cry by night, convey thy Deity
Aboard our dancing Boat, make ſwift the pangs
Of my Queens travels. Now, Lychorida.

speech.speaker: Lychor.
speech.line: Here is a thing too young for ſuch a place,
Who if it had conceit, would dye, as I am like to dœ:
Take in your armes this piece of your dead Queen.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: How? How, Lychorida?

speech.speaker: Lychor.
speech.line: Patience, good ſir, dœ not aſſiſt the ſtorme,
Here’s all that is left living of your Queen;
A little Daughter, for the ſake of it
Be manly, and take comfort.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Oh you gods!
Why dœ you make us love your goodly gifts,
And ſnatch them ſtraight away?
We here below, recall not what we give,
And we therein may uſe honor with you.

speech.speaker: Lychor.
speech.line: Patience, good ſir, even for this charge.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Now milde may be thy life,
For a more bluſterous birth had never Babe:
Quiet and gentle thy conditions;
For thou art the rudelieſt welcome to this world,
That ever was Princes Childe: happy that followes,
Thou haſt as chiding a Nativity,
As Fire, Aire, Water, Earth, and Heaven can make,
To harold thee from the wombe:
Even at the firſt, thy loſſe is more then can
Thy portage quite, with all thou canſt finde here:
Now the good gods throw their beſt eyes upon it.

speech.speaker: 1. Sayl.
speech.line: What courage, ſir? God ſave you.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Courage enough, I dœ not fear the flaw,
It hath done to me the worſt: yet for the love
Of this poor Infant, this freſh new Sea-farer,
I would it would be quiet.

speech.speaker: 1. Sayl.
speech.line: Slack the bolins there; thou wilt not, wilt thou?
Blow and ſplit thy ſelf.

speech.speaker: 2. Sayl.
speech.line: But Sea-room, and the brine and cloudy bil-
low kiſſe the Moon, I care not.

speech.speaker: 1. Sayl.
speech.line: Sir, your Queen muſt over board,
The Sea works high, the winde is loud,
And will not lie till the Ship be cleared of the dead.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: That’s your ſuperſtition.
Pardon us, ſir; with us at Sea it ſtill hath bin obſerved,
And we are ſtrong in Eaſtern, therefore briefly yield her.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: As you think meet, for ſhe muſt o’re-board ſtraight,
Moſt wretched Queen.

speech.speaker: Lychor.
speech.line: Here ſhe lies, ſir.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: A terrible Child-bed haſt thou had (my Dear)
No light, no fire, the unfriendly Elements
Forgot thee utterly, nor have I time
To give thee hallowed to thy grave, but ſtraight
Muſt caſt thee ſcarcely Coffind, in oare,
Where for a Monument upon thy bones.
The ayre remaining lamps, the belching Whale,
And humming water muſt o’rewhelme thy Corps,
Lying with ſimple ſhells: Oh Lychorida,
Bid Neſtor bring me Spices, Ink and Paper,
My casket and my Jewels, and bid Nicander
Bring me the Sattin Coffin; lay the Babe
Upon the Pillow; hie thee, whiles I ſay
A Prieſtly farewell to her: ſuddenly, woman.

speech.speaker: 2. Sayl.
speech.line: Sir, we have a Cheſt beneath the hatches,
Caulkt and bittumed ready.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I thank thee: Marriner ſay, what Coaſt is this?

speech.speaker: 2. Sayl.
speech.line: We are near Tharſus.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Thither, gentle Marriner,
Alter thy courſe for Tyre: when canſt thou reach it?

speech.speaker: 2. Sayl.
speech.line: By break of day, if the winde ceaſe.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: O make for Tharſus,
There will I viſit Cleon, for the Babe
Cannot hold out to Tyrus; there I’le leave it
At carefull nurſing: go thy wayes, good Marriner,
I’le bring the body preſently.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lord Cerymon with a Servant.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Phylemon, hoa.

speech.speaker: Phil.
speech.line: Doth my Lord call?

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Get fire and meat for theſe poor men,
It hath been a turbulent and ſtormy night.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I have been in many: but ſuch a night as this,
Till now, I ne’re endured.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Your Maſter will be dead ere you return,
There’s nothing can be miniſtred to nature,
That can recover him: give this to the Pothecary,
And tell me how it works.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: Good morrow.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: Good morrow to your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Gentlemen, why dœ you ſtirre ſo early?

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: Sir, our lodgings ſtanding bleak upon the Sea,
Shook as the earth did quake:
The very principles did ſeem to rend, and all to topple,
Pure ſurprize and fear made me to leave the houſe.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: That is the cauſe we trouble you ſo early,
’Tis not our husbandry.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: O you ſay well.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: But I much marvell that your Lordſhip
Having rich tire about you, ſhould at theſe early houres
Shake off the golden ſlumber of repoſe; ’tis moſt ſtrange,
Nature ſhould be ſo converſant with pain,
Being thereto not compelled.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: I hold it ever Virtue and Cunning.
Were endowments greater, then Nobleneſs and Riches,
Careleſs heirs may the two latter darken and expend;
But immortality attends the former,
Making a Man a God:
’Tis known, I ever have ſtudied Phyſick,
Through which ſecret Art, by turning o’re Authority,
I have together with my praƈtiſe, made familiar
To me and to my aide, the beſt infuſions that dwells
In vegetives, in Mettals, Stones: and can ſpeak of the
Diſturbances that Nature works, and of her cures;
Which doth give me a more content in courſe of true delight
Then to be thirſty after tottering Honour,
Or tye my pleaſure up in ſilken Bags,
To pleaſe the Fool and Death.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: Your honour has through Epheſus,
Poured forth your charity, and hundred call themſelves
Your Creatures; who by you have been reſtored,
And not your knowledge, your perſonall pain,
But even your purſe ſtill open, hath built Lord Cerimon
Such ſtrong renown, as never ſhall decay.

scene.stagedir: Enter two or three with a Cheſt.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: So, lift there.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: What’s that?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Sir, even now did the Sea, toſſe up upon our ſhore
This Cheſt; ’tis of ſome wrack.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Set it down, let us look upon it.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: ’Tis like a Coffin, ſir.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: What e’re it be, ’tis wondrous heavy;
Wrench it open ſtraight:
If the Seas ſtomack be o’re-charg’d with gold,
’Tis a good conſtraint of Fortune it belches upon us.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: ’Tis ſo, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: How cloſe ’tis caulkt and bottom’d, did the ſea caſt it up?

speech.speaker: Serv.
speech.line: I never ſaw ſo huge a billow, ſir, as toſt it upon
ſhore.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Wrench it open; it ſmells moſt ſweetly in my ſence.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: A delicate Odour.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: As ever hit my noſtrill: ſo, up with it.
Oh you moſt potent gods! what’s here, a Coarſe?

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: Moſt ſtrange.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Shrowded in cloth of ſtate, balm’d and entreaſured
With full bags of Spices, a Paſport to Apollo,
Perfeƈt me in the Charaƈters!

line.italic: Here I give to underſtand,
If e’re this Coffin drives a land;

speech.line: I King Pericles have loſt

line.italic: This Queen, worth all our mundane coſt:
Who finds her, give her burying,
She was the Daughter of a King.
Beſides this treaſure for a fee,
The gods requite his charity.

speech.line: If thou liveſt, Pericles, thou haſt a heart
That even cracks for wœ: this chanc’d to night.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: Moſt likely, ſir.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Nay certainly to night, for look how freſh ſhe looks,
They were too rough, that threw her in the ſea.
Make a fire within, fetch hither all my boxes in my Cloſet,
Death may uſurpe on Nature many houres,
And yet the fire of life kindle again the o’re-preſt ſpirits.
I heard of an Ægyptian that had nine houres been dead,
Who was by good appliance recovered.
speech.stagedir: Enter one with Napkins and Fire.
speech.line: Well ſaid, well ſaid, the fire and cloathes,
The rough and wofull muſick that we have,
Cauſe it to ſound I beſeech you:
The Viall once more; how thou ſtirrevt, thou block?
The Muſick there: I pray you give her aire;
Gentlemen, this Queen will live,
Nature awakes a warme breath out of her;
She hath not been entranſt above five houres,
See how ſhe gins to blow into lifes flower again.

speech.speaker: 1. Gen.
speech.line: The heavens through you, encreaſe our wonder,
And sets up your fame for ever.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: She is alive, behold her eye-lids,
Caſes to thoſe heavenly jewels which Pericles hath loſt,
Begin to part their fringes of bright gold
The Diamonds of a moſt praiſed water doth appear,
To make the world twice rich, live, and make us weep,
To hear your fate, fair creature, rare as you ſeem to be.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: O dear Diana, where am I? where’s my Lord?
What world is this?

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: Is not this ſtrange?

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: Moſt rare.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Huſh (my gentle neighbour) lend me your hands,
To the next chamber bear her, get linnen;
Now this matter muſt be lookt too, for the relapſe
Is mortall: come, come, and Eſculapius, guide us.

scene.stagedir: They carry her away. Exeunt omnes.
Enter Pericles at Tharſus, with Cleon and Dionizia.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Moſt honoured Cleon, I muſt needs be gone,
My twelve moneths are expir’d, and Tyre ſtands
In a peace: you and your Lady take from my heart
All thankfulneſſe. The gods make up the reſt upon you.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: Your ſhakes of fortune, though they hate you
Mortally, yet glance full wondringly on us.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: O your ſweet Queen! that the ſtriƈt fates had
You had brought her hither to have bleſt mine eyes with her.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: We cannot but obey the powers above us;
Could I rage and rore as doth the Sea ſhe lies in,
Yet the end muſt be as ’tis: my gentle babe Marina,
Whom (for ſhe was born at Sea) I have named ſo,
Here, I charge your charity withall; leaving her
The infant of your care, beſeeching you to give her
Princely training, that ſhe may be manner’d as ſhe is
born.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: Fear not (my Lord) but think your Grace,
That fed my Countrey with your Corn; for which,
The peoples prayers daily fall upon you, muſt in your
Childe
Be thought on, if negleƈt ſhould therein make me vile,
The common body that’s by you reliev’d,
Would force me to duty; but if to that,
My nature need a ſpurre, the gods revenge it
Upon me and mine, to the end of generation.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I believe you, your honour and your goodneſſe,
Teach me toot without your vowes, till ſhe be married,
Madam, by bright Diana, whom we honour,
All unſiſter’d ſhall this heir of mine remain,
Though I ſhew will in’t: ſo I take my leave:
Good Madam, make me bleſſed, in your care
In bringing up my Childe.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: I have one my ſelf, who ſhall not be more dear
to my reſpeƈt than yours, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Madam, my thanks and prayers.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: We’ll bring your Grace to the edge of the
ſhore, then give you up to the masked Neptune and the
gentleſt windes of heaven.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I will embrace your offer, come, deareſt Madam:
O no teares, Lychorida, no teares; look to your little
Miſtris, on whoſe grace you may depend hereafter:
come, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Madam, this Letter, and ſome certain Jewels,
Lay with you in your Coffer, which are at your command:
Know you the Charaƈter?

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: It is, my Lords, that I was ſhipt at Sea, I well
remember, even on my eaning time: but whether there
delivered, by the holy gods, I cannot rightly ſay: but
ſince King Pericles, my wedded Lord, I ne’re ſhall ſee
again, a veſtall livery will I take me to, and never more
have joy.

speech.speaker: Cer
speech.line: Madam, if this you purpoſe as ye ſpeak,
Dianæs Temple is not diſtant farre,
Where you may abide till your date expire,
Moreover if you pleaſe, a Neece of mine,
Shall there attend you.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: My recompence is thanks, that’s all,
Yet my good will is great, though the gift ſmall.

speech.speaker: Gower.
speech.line: Imagine Pericles arriv’d at Tyre,

line.italic: Welcom’d and ſettled to his own deſire;

speech.line: His wofull Queen we leave at Epheſus,
Unto Diana there’s a Votareſſe.
Now to Marina bend your minde,

line.italic: Whom our faſt growing ſcene muſt finde

speech.line: At Tharſus, and by Cleon train’d

line.italic: In Muſicks letters, who hath gain’d
Of education all the grace,
Which makes high both the art and place
Of generall wonder: but alack,
That monſter Envy oft the wrack

speech.line: Of earned praiſe, Marina’s life

line.italic: Seek to take off by treaſon’s knife,

speech.line: And in this kinde, our Cleon hath

line.italic: One Daughter and a full grown wench,
Even ripe for Marriage ſight: this Maid

speech.line: Hight Philoten: and it is ſaid

line.italic: For certain in our ſtory, ſhe

speech.line: Would ever with Marina be,

line.italic: Be’t when they weav’d the ſleded ſilk,
With fingers long, ſmall, white as milk,
Or when ſhe would with ſharp needle wound
The Cambrick, which ſhe made more ſound
By hurting it, or when to th’ Lute
She ſung, and made the night bed mute,
That ſtill records with one, or when
She would with rich and conſtant pen,

speech.line: Vaile to her Miſtreſſe Dion ſtill,
This Phyloten contends in ſkill
With abſolute Marina: ſo
The Dove of Paphos might with the Crow
Vie feathers white. Marina gets

line.italic: All praiſes, which are paid as debts,
And not as given, this ſo darks

speech.line: In Phyloten all gracefull markes,
That Cleon’s Wife, with envy rare,

line.italic: A preſent Murderer do’s prepare

speech.line: For good Marina, that her Daughter

line.italic: Might ſtand peerleſſe by this ſlaughter.
The ſooner her vile thoughts to ſtead,

speech.line: Lychorida our Nurſe is dead,
And curſed Dionizia hath

line.italic: The pregnant inſtrument of wrath
Preſt for this blow, the unborn event,
I dœ commend to your content,
Onely I carried winged Time,
Poſte on the lame feet of my rime,
Which never could I ſo convey,
Unleſse your thoughts went on my way.

speech.line: Dionizia doth appear,
With Leonine a Murderer.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Thy oath remember, thou haſt ſworn to do it,
’tis but a blow, which never ſhall be known, thou canſt
not dœ a thing in the world ſo ſoon, to yield thee ſo
much profit, let not conſcience, which is but cold, infla-
ming thy love boſome, enflame too nicely; nor let pitty,
which even women have caſt off, melt thee, but be a ſoul-
dier to thy purpoſe.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: I will do’t, but yet ſhe is a goodly Creature.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: The fitter then the gods ſhould have her.
Here ſhe comes weeping for her onely Miſtreſſe death:
Thou art reſolv’d?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: I am reſolv’d.

scene.stagedir: Enter Marina with a Basket of Flowers.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No: I will rob Tellus of her weed, to ſtrew thy
Grave with Flowers: the yellowes, blewes, the purple
Violets and Marigolds, ſhall as a Carpet hang upon thy
Grave, while Summer dayes doth laſt. Aye me, poor
Maid, born in a tempeſt when my Mother di’d: this
world to me is a laſting ſtorme, hurrying me from
my friends.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: How now, Marina? why de’ye weep alone?
How chance my Daughter is not with you?
Dœ not conſume your blood with ſorrowing,
You have a Nurſe of me. Lord? how your favour’s
Chang’d, with this unprofitable wœ:
Come give me your Flowers, ere the Sea marre it,
Walk with Leonine, the aire is quick there,
And it pierces and ſharpens the ſtomack;
Come, Leonine, take her by the arme, walk with her.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No, I pray you, I’le not bereave you of your
Servant.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Come, come, I love the King your Father, and
your ſelf, with more than forreign heart; we every day
expeƈt him here, when he ſhall come and finde our Para-
gon, to all reports thus blaſted. He will repent the breadth
of his great voyage, blame both my Lord and me, that we
have taken no care to your beſt courſes. Go I pray you,
walk and be cheerfull once again; reſerve that excellent
complexion, which did ſteale the eyes of young and old.
Care not for me, I can go home alone.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Well, I will go, but yet I have no deſire to it.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Come, come, I know ’tis good for you:
Walk half an houre, Leonine, at the leaſt.
Remember what I have ſaid.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: I warrant you, Madam.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: I’le leave you, my ſweet Lady, for a while: pray
walk ſoftly, dœ not heat your blood: What, I muſt have
a care of you.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My thanks, ſweet Madam. Is the winde Weſter-
ly that blowes?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: South-weſt.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: When I was born, the winde was North.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Was’t ſo?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My Father, as Nurſe faith, did never fear, but
cryed good Sea-men to the Sailors, galling his Kingly
hands, haling ropes, and claſping to the Maſt, endured a
Sea that almoſt burſt the deck.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: When was this?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: When I was born, never was waves nor winde
more violent, and from the ladder tackle, waſhes off a
Canvas clymer, ha, faith one, wilt out? and with a drop-
ping induſtry they skip from ſtern: the Boat-ſwain
whistles, and the Maſter calls and trebles their confuſion.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Come, ſay your prayers.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: What mean you?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: If you require a little ſpace for prayer, I grant
it, pray, but be not tedious, for the gods are quick of ear,
and I am ſworn to dœ my work with haſte.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Why, will you kill me?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: To ſatisfie my Lady.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Why would ſhe have me kill’d now? as I can
remember by my troth, I never did her hurt in all my
life, I never ſpake bad word, nor did ill turn to any li-
ving creature: believe me now, I never kill’d a Mouſe,
nor hurt a Flye. I trod upon a worme once againſt my
will, but I wept for it. How have I offended, wherein
my death might yield her any profit, or my life imply
her any danger?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: My Commiſſssion is not to reaſon of the deed,
but do’t.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: You will not do’t for all the world, I hope:
you are well favoured, and your looks fore-ſhew you have
a very gentle heart, I ſaw you lately when you caught
hurt in parting two that fought: good-ſooth it ſhewed
well in you, do ſo now, your Lady ſeeks my life, come you
between, and ſave poor me, the weaker.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: I am ſworn, and will diſpatch.

speech.speaker: Pirat. 1.
speech.line: Hold villain.

speech.speaker: Pirat. 2.
speech.line: A prize, a prize.

speech.speaker: Pirat. 3.
speech.line: Half part mates, half part. Come lets have
her aboard ſodainly.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Theſe roguing thieves ſerve the great Pirate Val-
des, and they have ſeized Marina, let her go, there’s no
hope ſhe will return: I’le ſwear ſhe’s dead, and thrown
into the Sea, but I’le ſee further, perhaps they will but
pleaſe themſelves upon her, not carry her aboard, if ſhe
remain,
Whom they have raviſht muſt by me be ſlain.

speech.speaker: Pander.
speech.line: Boult.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Sir.

speech.speaker: Pander.
speech.line: Search the market narrowly, Metaline is full
of gallants, we loſt too much money this Mart, by being
too Wenchleſſe.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: We were never ſo much out of creatures, we
have but poor three, and they can dœ no more then they
can dœ, and they with continuall aƈtion, are even as
good as rotten.

speech.speaker: Pander.
speech.line: Therefore let’s have freſh ones what e’re we
pay for them, if there be not a conſcience to be us’d in
every trade, we ſhall never proſper.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Thou ſay’ſt true, ’tis not our bringing up of
poor baſtards, as I think, I have brought up ſome eleven.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I too eleven, and brought them down again,
But ſhall I ſearch the market?

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: What elſe, man? The ſtuffe we have, a ſtrong
winde will blow it to pieces, they are ſo pitifully ſodden.

speech.speaker: Pander.
speech.line: Thou ſay’ſt true, there’s two unwholeſome in
conſcience, the poor Tranſilvanian is dead that lay with
the little baggage.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I, ſhe quickly poupt him, ſhe made him roaſt-
meat for wormes, but I’le go ſearch the market.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Three or four thouſand Chickeens were as pretty
a proportion to live quietly, and ſo give over.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Why, to give over, I pray you? Is it a ſhame
to get when we are old?

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Oh our credit comes not in like the commodity,
nor the commodity wages not with the danger: there-
fore, if in our youths we could pick up ſome pretty eſtate,
’twere not amiſſe to keep our door hatch’d; beſides the
ſore termes we ſtand upon with the gods, will be ſtrong
with us for giving o’re.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Come, other ſorts offend as well as we.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: As well as we, I, and better too, we offend worſe,
neither is our profession any Trade, it’s no calling: but
here comes Boult.

scene.stagedir: Enter Boult with the Pirates, and Mirana.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Come your wayes, my maſters, you ſay ſhe’s a virgin?

speech.speaker: Sayl.
speech.line: O ſir, we doubt it not.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Maſter, I have gone through for this piece you ſee,
If you like her, ſo; if not, I have loſt my earneſt.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Boult, has ſhe any qualities?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: She has a good face, ſpeaks well, and has ex-
cellent good cloathes: there’s no farther neceſſity of qua-
lities can make her be refuſed.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: What’s her price, Boult?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I cannot be bated one doit of a thouſand pieces.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Well, follow me, my Maſters, you ſhall have
your money preſently: wife, take her in, inſtruƈt her
what ſhe has to dœ, that ſhe may not be raw in her en-
tertainment.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Boult, take you the markes of her, the colour
of her haire, complexion, height, age, with warrant of her
virginity, and cry; He that will give moſt, ſhall have her
firſt. Such a maiden-head were no cheap thing, if men
were as they have been: Get this done as I command you.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Performance ſhall follow.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Alack that Leonine was ſo ſlack, ſo ſlow:
He ſhould have ſtruck, not ſpoke;
Or that theſe Pirates, not enough barbarous,
Had not o’re-board thrown me, for to ſeek my Mother.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Why weep you, pretty one?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: That I am pretty.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Come, the gods have done their part in you.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I accuſe them not.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: You are light into my hands,
Where you are like to live.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The more’s my fault, to ſcape his hands,
Where I was like to dye.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: I, and you ſhall live in pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Yes indeed ſhall you, and taſte Gentlemen of
all faſhions. You ſhall fare well; you ſhall have the dif-
ference of all complexions: what de’ye ſtop your eares?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Are you a woman?

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: What would you have me be, if I be not a
woman?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: An honeſt woman, or not a woman.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Marry whip thee, Goſling: I think I ſhall have
ſomething to dœ with you. Come, y’are a young fooliſh
ſapling, and musſt be bowed as I would have ye.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The gods defend me.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: If it pleaſe the gods to defend you by men,
then men muſt comfort you, men muſt feed you, men muſt
ſtirre you up: Boult’s return’d.
Now, ſir, haſt thou cry’d her through the Market?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I have cri’d her almoſt to the number of her hairs,
I have drawn her piƈture with my voice.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: And I prithee tell me, how do’ſt thou find the in-
clination of the people, eſpecially of the younger ſort?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Faith they liſtened to me, as they would have
hearkned to their father’s Teſtament. There was a Spaniards
mouth ſo watered, that he went to bed to her very deſcri-
ption.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: We ſhall have him here to morrow with his
beſt ruffe on.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: To night, to night, but, Miſtriſ, do you know
the French Knight that cowres i’the hams?

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: Who, Monſieur Verollus?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I, he offered to cut a caper at the proclamation,
but he made a groan at it, and ſwore he would ſee her to
morrow.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: Well, well, as for him he brought his diſeaſe
