hither, here he doth but repair it, I know he will come
in our ſhadow, to ſcatter his crowns in the ſun.

speech.speaker: Bould.
speech.line: Well, if we had of every Nation a traveller,
we ſhould lodge them with this ſigne.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: Pray you come hither a while, you have For-
tunes comming upon you, mark me, you muſt ſeem to do
that fearfully, which you commit willingly, deſpiſe pro-
fit, where you have moſt gain, to weep that you live as
you do, makes pitty in your lovers ſeldome, but that pit-
ty begets you a good opinion, and that opinion a meer
profit.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I underſtand you not.

speech.speaker: Bould.
speech.line: O take her home, miſtris, take her home, theſe
bluſhes of hers muſt be quencht with ſome preſent praƈtiſe.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: Thou ſayeſt true ifaith, ſo they muſt, for your
Bride gœs to that with ſhame, which is her way to go
with warrant.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Faith, ſome do, and ſome do not, but, Miſtris,
if I have bargain’d for the joynt.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: Thou maiſt cut a morſel off the ſpit.

speech.speaker: Bould.
speech.line: I may ſo.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: Who ſhould deny it?
Come young one, I like the manner of your garments well.

speech.speaker: Bould.
speech.line: I by my faith, they ſhall not be changed yet.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: Boult, ſpend thou that in the Town, report
what a ſojourner we have, you’ll loſe nothing by cuſtome.
When nature framed this piece, ſhe meant thee a good
turn, therefore ſay what a parragon ſhe is, and thou haſt
the harveſt out of thine own report.

speech.speaker: Bould.
speech.line: I warrant you miſtris, thunder ſhall not ſo
awake the beds of Eels, as my giving out her beauty ſtirs
up the lewdly enclined, I’le bring home ſome to night.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: Come your wayes, follow me.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: If fires be hot, knives ſharp, or waters deep,
Unti’d I ſtill my virgin knot will keep.
Diana aid my purpoſe.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: What have we to do with Diana? pray you
go with us?

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Why are you fooliſh, can it be undone?

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: O Dionizia, ſuch a piece of ſlaughter,
The Sun and Moon ne’re look’d upon.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: I think you’ll turn a child again.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: Were I chief Lord of all this ſpacious world,
I’d give it to undo the deed. O Lady, much leſs in bloud,
then vertue, yet a Princeſs to equall any ſingle Crown of
the earth, in the juſtice of compare, O villain, Leonine
whom thou haſt poiſoned too, if thou had’ſt drunk to him,
it had been a kindneſs becoming well thy face, what canſt
thou ſay, when Noble Pericles ſhall demand his child?

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: That ſhe is dead. Nurſes are not the fates to
foſter it, nor ever to preſerve, ſhe di’d at night, I’le ſay
ſo, who can croſſe it, unleſſe you play the Innocent, and
for an honeſt attribute, cry out ſhe di’d by foul play.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: O go too, well, well, of all the faults beneath
the heavens, the gods do like this worſt.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Be one of thoſe that thinks the pretty wrens
of Tharſus will fly hence, and open this to Pericles;
I do ſhame to think of what Noble ſtrain you are, and
of how coward a ſpirit.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: To ſuch proceeding, who ever but his approba-
tion added, though not his whole conſent, he did not flow
from honorable courſes.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Be it ſo then, yet none doth know but you
how ſhe came dead, nor none can know, Leonine being
gone. She did diſdain my child, and ſtood between her
and her fortunes: none would look on her, but caſt their
gazes on Marina’s face, whilſt ours was blurred at, and
held a Mawkin, not worth the time of day. It pierc’d
me thorow, and though you call my courſe unnatural,
you not your child well loving, yet I find it greets me as
an enterprize of kindneſs perform’d to your ſole daughter.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: Heavens forgive it.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: And as for Pericles, what ſhould he ſay? we
wept after her hearſe, and yet we mourn: her monument
almoſt finiſhed, and her Epitaph in glittering golden
chara’ters, expreſs a general praiſe to her, and care in us,
at whoſe expence ’tis done.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: Thou art like the Harpie,
Which to betray, doſt with thy Angels face,
Ceaze with thine Eagles talents.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: You are like one, that ſuperſtitiouſly
Doth ſwear to th’gods, that winter kills the flies,
But yet I know, you’ll do as I adviſe.

line.italic: Thus time we waſte, and long leagues make ſhort,
Sail ſeas in Cockles, have and wiſh but for’t:
Making to take our imagination,
From bourn to bourn, Region to Region.
By you being Pard’ned, we commit no crime
To uſe one Language, in each ſeveral clime,
Where our ſcenes ſeems to live. I do beſeech you
To learn of me, who ſtand in gaps to teach you,

speech.line: The ſtages of our ſtory Pericles,

line.italic: Is now again thwarting the wayward ſeas;
(Attended on by many a Lord and Knight)
To ſee his daughter, all his lives delight.

speech.line: Old Hellicanus gœs along behinde,

line.italic: Is left to govern it: you bear in minde

speech.line: Old Eſcanes, whom Helicanus late

line.italic: Advanc’d in time to great and high eſtate.
Well ſailing ſhips, and bounteous windes have brought

speech.line: This King to Tharſus think his Pilate thought,

line.italic: So with his ſteerage, ſhall your thoughts grone
To fetch his Daughter home, who firſt is gone
Like moats and ſhadowes ſee them move a while,
Your eares unto your eyes I’le reconcile.

scene.stagedir: Enter Pericles at one door with all his train. Cleon and Dionizia at the other. Cleon ſhewes Pericles the Tombe, whereat Pericles makes lamentation, puts on Sack-cloth, and in a mighty paſſion departs.

speech.speaker: Gower.

line.italic: See how belief may ſuffer by foule ſhow,
This borrowed paſſion ſtands for true old wœ:

speech.line: And Pericles in ſorrow all devour’d,

line.italic: With ſighes ſhot through, and biggeſt teares o’re-ſhowr’d.

speech.line: Leaves Tharſus, and again imbarks, he ſweares

line.italic: Never to waſh his face, nor cut his haires,
He puts on Sack-cloth and to Sea he beares,
A tempeſt which his mortall Veſſell teares.
And yet he rides it out. Now take we our way

speech.line: The Epitaph is for Marina writ by Dionizia
The faireſt, ſweeteſt, and beſt lies here,
Who withered in her ſpring of year:
She was of Tyrus the King’s Daughter,
On whom foule death hath made this ſlaughter:
Marina was ſhe call’d, and at her birth,
That is, being proud, ſwallow’d ſome part of th’earth:
Therefore the earth fearing to be o’reflow’d
Hath Thetis birth-childe on the heavens beſtow’d;
Wherefore ſhe dœs, and ſweares ſhe’ll never ſtint,
Make raging Battry upon ſhores of flint.

line.italic: No vizor dœs become black villany,
So well as ſoft and tender flattery.

speech.line: Let Pericles believe his Dauhter’s dead,

line.italic: And bear his courſes to be ordered

speech.line: By Lady Fortune, while our ſteare muſt play

line.italic: His Daughter wœ and heavy well-a-day.
In her unholy ſervice: Patience then,

speech.line: And think you now are all in Metaline.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: Did you ever hear the like?

speech.speaker: 2. Gend.
speech.line: No, nor never ſhall dœ in ſuch a place as
this, ſhe being once gone.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: But to have Divinity preacht there, did you
ever dreame of ſuch a thing?

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: No, no, come, I am for no more Bawdy
Houſes, ſhall we go hear the Veſtalls ſing?

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: I’le dœ any thing now that is virtuous, but
I am out of the road of rutting for ever.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Well, I had rather then twice the worth of her
ſhe had ne’re come here.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Fie, fie upon her, ſhe is able to frieze the god
Priapus, and undœ a whole generation, we muſt either
get her raviſht, or be rid of her, when ſhe ſhould dœ for
clyents her fitment, and dœ me the kindneſſe of our pro-
feſſion, ſhe has me her quirks, her reaſons, her maſter-
reaſons, her prayers, her knees, that ſhe would make a
Puritane of the Devil, if he ſhould cheapen a kiſſe of her.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Faith I muſt raviſh her, or ſhe’ll disfurniſh us
of all our Cavaleers, and make our Swearers Prieſts.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Now the poxe upon her green ſickneſſe for me.

speech.speaker: Ba.
speech.line: Faith there’s no way to be rid of it, but by the way
to the Pox. Here comes the Lord Lyſimachus diſguiſed.

speech.speaker: Boul.
speech.line: We ſhould have both Lord and Lown, if the
peeviſh Baggage would but give way to cuſtomers.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: How now, how a dozen of virginities?

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Now the gods bleſſe your Honour.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I am glad to ſee your Honour in good health.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: You may ſo, ’tis the better for you, that your
reſorters ſtand upon ſound Legs, how now? wholeſome
impunity have you, that a man may deale withall and
defy the Surgeon?

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: We have here one, ſir, if ſhe would—
But there never came her like in Metaline.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: If ſhe’d dœ the deeds of darkneſſe, thou wouldſt
ſay.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: Your honour knowes what ’tis to ſay well e-
nough.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Well, call forth, call forth.

speech.speaker: Bould.
speech.line: For fleſh and blood, ſir, white and red, you
ſhall ſee a Roſe, and ſhe were a Roſe indeed, if ſhe had
but—

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: What prethee?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: O ſir, I can be modeſt.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: That dignifies the renown of a Bawd, no leſſe
then it gives a good report to a number to be chaſte.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Here comes that which growes to the ſtalke,
Never pluckt yet I can aſſure you.
Is ſhe not a fair creature?

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Faith ſhe would ſerve after a long voyage at Sea,
Well, there’s for you, leave us.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: I beſeech your honor give me leave a word,
and I’le have done preſently.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: I beſeech you dœ.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Firſt, I would have you note, this is an honou-
rable man.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I deſire to find him ſo, that I may worthily
note him.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Next, he’s the Governour of this Country, and
a man whom I am bound to.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: If he govern the Countrey, you are bound to
him indeed, but how honourable he is in that, I know not.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Pray you, without any more virginall fencing,
will you uſe him kindly? he will line your Apron with
Gold.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: What he will dœ graciouſly, I will thankfully
receive.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Have you done?

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: My Lord, ſhe’s not pace’t yet, you muſt take
ſome pains to work her to your mannage, come, we will
leave his Honour and her together.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Now, pretty one, how long have you been at this
trade?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: What trade, Sir?

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Why, I cannot name’t but I ſhall offend.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I cannot be offended with my trade, pleaſe you
to name it.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: How long have you been of this profeſſion?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: E’er ſince I can remember.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Did you go to’t ſo young, were you a gameſter
at five, or at ſeven?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Earlier too, ſir, if now I be one,

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Why the houſe you dwell in, proclaimes you to
be a creature of ſale.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Dœ you know this houſe to be a place of ſuch
reſort, and will come into it? I hear ſay you are of ho-
nourable parts, and the Governour of this place.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Why? hath your principall made known unto
you, who I am?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Who is my Principal?

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Why your hearb woman, ſhe that ſets ſeeds and
roots of ſhame and iniquity. O you have heard ſome
thing of my power, and ſo ſtand aloft for more ſerious
wooing, but I proteſt to thee, pretty one, my authority
ſhall not ſee thee, or elſe look friendly upon thee; come
bring me to ſome private place, come, come.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: If you were born to honour, ſhew it now, if put
upon you, make the judgment good, that thought you
worthy of it.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: How’s this? how’s this? ſome more, be ſage.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: For me that am maid, though moſt ungentle
Fortune have plac’d me in this Stie, where ſince I came,
diſeaſes have been ſold dearer then Phyſick, O that the
gods would ſet me free from this unhallow’d place,
though they did change me to the meaneſt bird that flies
i’th purer aire.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: I did not think thou could’ſt have ſpoke ſo well,
I ne’re dream’d thou could’ſt; had I brought hither a
corrupted mind, thy ſpeech had altered it, hold, here’s
gold for thee, perſever in that clear way thou gœſt, and
the gods ſtrengthen thee.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The good gods preſerve you.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: For my part, I cmae with no ill intent, for to me
the very doors and windows ſavours vilely, fare thee well,
thou art a piece of vertue, and I doubt not but thy train-
ing hath been Noble, hold, here’s more gold for thee, a
curſe upon him, die he life a thief that robs thee of they
goodneſs, if thou doſt hear from me, it ſhall be for thy
good.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I beſeech your honour one piece for me.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Avant thou damned door-keeper, your houſe but
for this virgin that doth prop it, would ſink and over-
whelm you. away.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: How’s this? we muſt take another courſe with
you? if your peeviſh chaſtity, which is not worth a
break-faſt in the cheapeſt Country under the coap, ſhall
undo a whole houſehold, let me be gelded like a ſpaniel,
come your wayes.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Whither would you have me?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I muſt have your maidenhead taken off, or the
common hangman ſhall execute it, come your way, we’ll
have no more gentlemen driven away, come your wayes
I ſay.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: How now, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Worſe and worſe, Miſtris, ſhe hath here ſpo-
ken holy words to the Lord Lyſimachus.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: O abominable.

speech.speaker: Bould.
speech.line: He makes our profeſſion as it were to ſtink be-
fore the face of the gods.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Marry hang her up for ever.

speech.speaker: Bould.
speech.line: The Nobleman would have dealt with her like
a Nobleman, and ſhe ſent him away as cold as a Snow-
ball, ſaying his prayers too.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Boult, take her away, uſe her at thy pleaſure.
crack the glaſſe of her virginity, & make the reſt maleable.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: And if ſhe were a thornier piece of ground
then ſhe is, ſhe ſhall be ploughed.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Hark, hark, you gods.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: She conjures, away with her, would ſhe had
never come within my doors, Marry hang you, ſhe’s born
to undo us, will you not go the way of women-kind?
Marry come up my diſh of chaſtity, with roſemary and
bayſe

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Come miſtris, come your wayes with me.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Whither would you have me?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: To take from you the jewel you hold ſo deer.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Prithee tell me one thing firſt.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Come now, your one thing.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: What can’ſt thou wiſh thine enemy to be?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Why I could wiſh him to be my Maſter, or
rather my Miſtris.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Neither of theſe are ſo bad as thou art, ſince
they do better thee in their command; though hold’ſt
a place, for which the painedſt fiend in hell would
not in reputation change: thou art the damned door-
keeper to every cuſherel that comes enquiring for his
Tib; to the cholerick fiſting of every rogue, thy ear is
liable, thy food is ſuch as hath been belcht on by infe-
ƈtious lungs.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: What would you have me do? go to the warrs,
would you, where a man may ſerve ſeven years for the
loſſe of a leg, and have not money enough in the end to
buy him a wooden one?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Do any thing but this thou doſt, empty old re-
ceptacles, or common-ſhores of filth; ſerve by Indenture
to the common hangman, any of theſe wayes are yet bet-
ter then this: for what thou profeſſeſt, a Baboon, could he
ſpeak, would own a name too dear: Oh, that the gods
would ſafely deliver me from this place: here, here’s gold
for thee, if that thy Maſter would gain by me, proclaim
that I can ſing, weave, ſowe, and dance, with other ver-
tues, which I’le keep from boaſt, and will undertake all
theſe to teach. I doubt not but this populous City will
yield many ſchollars.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: But can you teach all this you ſpeak off?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Prove that I cannot, take me home again, and
proſtitute me to the baſeſt groom that doth frequent your
houſe.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Well, I will ſee what I can do for thee: If I
can place thee I will.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: But amongſt honeſt women.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Faith, my acquaintance lies little among them;
but ſince my maſter and miſtris hath bought you, there’s
no going but by their conſent: therefore I will make them
acquainted with your purpoſe, and I doubt not but I ſhall
find them traƈtable enough. Come, I’le do for thee what
I can, come your wayes.
Marina thus the Brothel ſcapes, and chances

line.italic: Into an honeſt houſe, our ſtory ſaies;
She ſings like one immortal, and ſhe dances
As goddeſs-like to her admired laies:
Deep Clearks ſhe dumbs, and with her needle compoſes
Natures own ſhape, of bud, bird, branch, or berry,
That even her art, ſiſters the natural Roſes,
Her Incle, Silk, Twine, with the rubied Cherry,
That pupils lacks ſhe none of noble race,
Who pour their bounty on her, and her gain
She gives the curſed Bawd. Leave we her place,
And to her Father turn our thoughts again,
Where we left him at ſea, tumbled and toſt,
And driven before the wind, he is arriv’d
Here where his daughter dwels, and on this Coaſt,
Suppoſe him now at Anchor: the City ſtriv’d

speech.line: God Neptunes annual feaſt to keep, from whence
Lyſimachus our Tyrian ſhip eſpies,

line.italic: His banners ſable, trim’d with rich expence,
And to him in his Barge with fervour hyes.
In your ſuppoſing, once more put your ſight

speech.line: Of heavy Pericles, think this his Bark;

line.italic: Where what is done in aƈtion (more if might
Shall be diſcovered) pleaſe you ſit and hark.

scene.stagedir: Enter Hellicanus, to him two Saylors.

speech.speaker: 1. Sayl.
speech.line: Where is Lord Hellicanus? he can re-
ſolve you. O here he is, ſir, there is a Barge put off from
Metaline,and in it is Lyſimachus the Governor, who
craves to come aboard, what is your will?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: That he have his, call up ſome gentlemen.

speech.speaker: 2. Sayl.
speech.line: Ho, Gentlemen, my Lord calls.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Gentlemen, there is ſome of worth would come
aboard, I pray thee greet him fairly.

speech.speaker: 1. Sayl.
speech.line: Sir, this is the man that can in ought you
would, reſolve you.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Hail, reverent ſir, the gods preſerve you.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: And you to out-live the age I am, and die as I
would do.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: You wiſh me well; being on ſhore, honoring
of Neptunes triumphs, ſeeing this goodly veſſel ride before
us, I made to it to know of whence you are.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Firſt, what is your place?

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: I am the Governor of this place you lie before.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Sir, our veſſel’s of Tyre, in it the King, a man,
who for this three months hath not ſpoken to any one,
nor taken ſuſtenance, but to prolong his grief.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Upon what ground is his diſtemperance?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: It would be too tedious to repeat, but the main
grief ſprings from the loſſe of a beloved daughter, and a
wife.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: May we not ſee him?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: You may, but bootleſs is your ſight, he will not
ſpeak to any.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Let me obtain my wiſh.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Behold him, this was a goodly perſon, till the
diſaſter that one mortal wight, drove him to this.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Sir King, all hail, the gods preſerve you, hail,
Royal Sir.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: It is in vain, he will not ſpeak to you.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Sir, we have a maid in Metaline, I durſt wager
would win ſome words of him.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: ’Tis well bethought, ſhe queſtionleſſe with her
ſweet harmony, and other choſen attraƈtions, would al-
lure and make a battery through his deafended parts, which
now are mid-way ſtopt, ſhe is all happy, as the faireſt of
all, and with her fellow maids, is now upon the levie ſhelter that
abutts againſt the Iſland ſide.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Sure all effeƈtleſs yet nothing wee’l omit that
bears recoveries name. But ſince your kindneſs we have
ſtretcht thus farre, let us beſeech you, that for our gold we
may have proviſion, wherein we are not deſtitute for want,
but weary for the ſtaleneſs.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: O, ſir, a courteſie, which if we ſhould deny, the
moſt juſt God for every graffe would ſend a Caterpiller,
and ſo infliƈt our Province: yet once more let me entreat
to know at large the cauſe of your Kings ſorrow.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Sit, ſir, I will recount it to you; but ſee, I am
prevented.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: O here’s the Lady that I ſent for.
Welcome fair one: Is’t not a goodly preſent?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: She’s a gallant Lady.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: She’s ſuch a one, that were I well aſſur’d,
Came of a gentle kind and noble ſtock,
I’d wiſh no better choiſe, and think me rarely wed.
Fair and all goodneſſe that conſiſts in beauty,
Expeƈt even here, where is a kingly patient,
If that thy proſperous and artificial fate,
Can draw him but to anſwer thee in ought,
Thy ſacred Phyſick ſhall receive ſuch pay,
As thy deſires can wiſh.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Sir, I will uſe my utmoſt ſkill in his recovery,
provided that none but I and my companion maid, be
ſuffered to come near him.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Come, let us leave her, and the gods make her
proſperous.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Markt he your muſick:

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No, nor lookt on us.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: See, ſhe will ſpeak to him.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Hail, ſir, my Lord, lend ear.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Hum, ha.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I am a maid, my Lord, that nere before invited
eyes, but have been gazed on like a Comet: ſhe ſpeaks, my
Lord, that may be, hath endured a grief might equall
yours, if both were juſtly weighed, though wayward for-
tune did maligne my ſtate, my derivation was from an-
ceſtors who ſtood equivolent with mighty Kings, but time
hath rooted out my parentage, and to the world and auk-
ward caſualties, bound me in ſervitude, I will deſiſt, but
there is ſomething glows upon my cheek, and whiſpers in
mine ear, Go not till he ſpeak.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: My fortunes, parentage, good parentage to equal
mine; was it not thus, what ſay you?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I ſaid, my Lord, if you did know my parentage,
you would not do me violence.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I do think ſo, pray you turn your eyes upon me,
y’are like ſome-thing that, what Countrey-women hear of
theſe ſhews?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No, nor of any ſhews, yet I was mortally
brought forth, and am no other then I appear.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I am great with wœ, and ſhall deliver weeping:
my deareſt wife was like this maid, and ſuch a one my
daughter might have been: my Queens square brows, her
ſtature to an inch, as wand-like ſtraight, as ſilver voyc’ſt,
her eyes as jewel-like, and caſt as richly, in pace another
Juno. Who ſtarves the ears ſhe feeds, and makes them,
hungry, the more ſhe gives them ſpeech; where do you
live?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Where I am but a ſtranger, from the deck you
may diſcern the place.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Where were you bred? and how atchiev’d
you theſe endowments which you make more rich
to owe?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: If I ſhould tell my hiſtory, it would ſeem like
lies diſdain’d in the reporting.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Prithee ſpeak, falſeneſſe cannot come from
thee, for thou lookeſt modeſt Juſtice, and thou ſeem’ſt
a Pallas for the crowned truth to dwell in, I will believe
thee, and make my ſenſes credite thy relation, to
points that ſeem impoſſible, for thou look’ſt like one
I loved indeed; what were thy friends? Did’ſt thou
not ſtay when I did puſh thee back; which was when
I perceived thee that thou cam’ſt from good deſcent.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: So indeed I did.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Report thy parentage, I think thou ſaid’ſt thou
had’ſt been toſt from wrong to injury, and that thou
thought’ſt thy griefs might equall mine, if both were o-
pened.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Some ſuch thing I ſaid, and ſaid no more,
but what my thoughts did warrant me was likely.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Tell thy ſtory, if thine conſidered prove the
thouſand part of my endurance, thou art a man, and I
have ſuffered like a girle, tet thou do’ſt look like patience,
gazing on Kings graves, and ſmiling extremity out of
aƈt, what were thy friends? how loſt thou thy name,
my moſt kind virgin? recount I do beſeech thee, Come
ſit by me.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My name is Marina.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Oh I am mockt, and thou by ſome inſenced god
ſent hither to make the world to laugh at me.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Patience, good ſir, or here I’le ceaſe.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Nay I’le be patient, thou little know’ſt how thou
dœſt ſtartle me to call thy ſelf Marina.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The name was given me by one that had ſome
power, my father and a King.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: How, a Kings daughter, and call’d Marina?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: You ſaid you would believe me, but not to be a
trouble of your peace, I will end here.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: But are you fleſh and bloud?
Have you a working pulſe, and are no Fairy?
Motion? well ſpeak on, where were you born?
And wherefore call’d Marina?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Call’d Marina, for I was born at ſea.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: At ſea? who was thy mother?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My mother was the Daughter of a King, who
died the minute I was born, as my good Nurſe Lychori-
da hath oft delivered weeping.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: O ſtop there a little, this is the rareſt dream
That ere dull ſleep did mock ſad fools withall,
This cannot be my daughter; buried! well, where were
you bred? I’le hear you more to the bottome of your ſtory
and never interrupt you.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: You ſcorn, believe me ’twere beſt I did give ore.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I will believe you by the ſyllable of what you
ſhall deliver, yet give me leave, how came you in theſe
parts? where were you bred?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The King my Father did in Tharſus leave me,
Till cruel Cleon with his wicked wife,
Did ſeek to murther me: and having woœd a villain
To attempt it, who having drawn to do’t,
A crew of Pyrats came and reſcued me,
Brought me to Metaline
But, good ſir, whether will you have me? why do you weep?
It may be you think me an impoſture, no good faith. I am
the daughter to King Pericles, if good King Pericles be.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Hœ, Hel.icanus?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Call’s my Lord?

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Thou art a grave and noble Counſellor,
Moſt wiſe in general, tell me if thou can’ſt, what this
maid is,
Or what is like to be, that thus hath made me weep?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: I know not, but here’s the Regent, ſir, of Me-
taline, ſpeaks nobly of her.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: She never would tell her parentage,
Being demanded that, ſhe would ſit ſtill and weep.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Oh Hellicanus, ſtrike me, honored ſir, give me
a gaſh, put me to preſent pain, leaſt this great ſea of
joyes ruſhing upon me, ore-bear the ſhores of my mor-
tality, and drown me with their ſweetneſſe: Oh come
hither,
Thou that beget’ſt him that did thee beget,
Thou that waſt born at ſea, buried at Tharſus,
And found at ſea again: O Hellicanus,
Down on thy knees, thank the holy gods, as loud
As thunder threatens us; this is Marina.
What was thy mother’s name? tell me but that,
For truth can never be confirm’d enough,
Though doubts did ever ſleep.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Firſt, ſir, I pray what is your Title?

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I am Pericles of Tyre, but tell me now my
Droun’d Queens name, as in the reſt you ſaid,
Thou haſt been god-like perfeƈt, the heir of Kingdomes,
And another like to Pericles thy father.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Is it no more to be your daughter, then to ſay,
my Mothers name is Thaiſa? Thaiſa was my mother,
who did end the minute I began.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Now bleſſing on thee, riſe, thou art my child.
Give me freſh garments, mine own Hellicanus, ſhe is not
dead at Tharſus, as ſhe ſhould have been by ſavage
Cleon, ſhe ſhall tell thee all, when thou ſhalt kneel, and
juſtifie in knowledge, ſhe is thy very Princes; who is
this?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Sir, ’tis the Governor of Metaline, who hear-
ing of your melancholly, did come to ſee you.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I embrace you; give me my robes;
I am wild in my beholding. Oh heaven bleſſe my girle.
But hark, what Muſick’s this Hellincanus? my Marina,
Tell him ore point by point, for yet he ſeems to doat,
How ſure you are my daughter; but where’s this muſick?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: My Lord, I hear none.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: None? the muſick of the ſphears, liſt my Marina.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: It is not good to croſſe him, give him way.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Rareſt ſounds, do ye not hear?

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Muſick, my Lord, I hear.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Moſt heavenly muſick,
It nips me unto liſtning, and thick ſlumber
Hangs upon mine eyes, let me reſt.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: A pillow for his head, ſo leave him all.
Well my companion friends, if this but anſwer to my
juſt belief, I’le well remember you.

speech.speaker: Diana.
speech.line: My Temple ſtands in Epheſus,
Hie thee thither, and do upon mine Altar ſacrifice. There
when my maiden prieſts are met together, before all the
peaople reveale how thou at ſea did’ſt loſe thy wife, to
mourn thy croſſes with thy daughters call, and give
them repetition to the like: or performe my bidding, or
thou liveſt in wœ: do’t, and happy, by my ſilver bow;
awake and tell thy dream.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Celeſtial Dian, Goddeſs Argentine,
I will obey thee: Hellicanus.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: My purpoſe was for Tharſus, there to ſtrike
The inhoſpitable Cleon, but I am for other ſervice firſt,
Toward Epheſus turn our blown ſayls,
Eftſoons I’le tell thee why, ſhall we refreſh us, ſir, upon your
ſhore, and give you gold for such proviſion as our intents
will need.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Sir, with all my heart, and when you come aſhore,
I have another ſleight.

speech.speaker: Pericl.
speech.line: You ſhall prevaile, were it to woœ my
daughter, for it ſeems you have been noble towards her.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Sir, lend me your arme.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Come, my Marina.

line.italic: Now our ſands are almoſt run,
More a little, and then dum.
This my laſt boon give me,
For ſuch kindneſs muſt relieve me:
That you aptly will ſuppoſe,
What pageantry, what feats, what ſhews,
What Minſtrelſie, and pretty din,

speech.line: The Regent made in Metalin,

line.italic: To greet the King; ſo he thrived,
That he is promiſed to be wived

speech.line: To fair Marina, but in no wiſe,

line.italic: Till he had done his ſacrifice,

speech.line: As Dian bad, whereto being bound,

line.italic: The Interim pray you, all confound.
In fether’d briefneſs ſayls are fill’d,
And wiſhes fall out as their will’d.

speech.line: At Epheſus the Temple ſee,

line.italic: Our King, and all his company.
That he can hither come ſo ſoon
Is by your fancies thank full doom.

scene.stagedir: Enter Pericles, Lyſimachus, Hellicanus, Marina, and others.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Hail Dian, to performe thy juſt command,
I here confeſs my ſelf the King of Tyre.
Who frighted from my Country, did wed at Pentapolis,
the fair Thaiſa, at ſea in childbed died ſhe, but brought
forth a Maid childe called Marina, whom, O goddeſſe,
wears yet thy ſilver livery, ſhe at Tharſus was nurſt with
Cleon, who at fourteen years he ſought to murder, but her
better ſtars brought her to Metaline, ’gainſt whoſe ſhore
riding, her fortunes brought the maid aboard us, where
by her own moſt clear remembrance, ſhe made known
her ſelf my daughter.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: Voice and favour, you are, you are, O royal Pericles.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: What means the woman? ſhe dies, help gentlemen.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Sir, if you have told Diana’s Altar true, this is
your wife.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Reverend appearer, no, I threw her over-board
with theſe very armes.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Upon this Coaſt, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: ’Tis moſt certain.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Look to the Lady; O ſhe’s but overjoy’d.
Early in bluſt’ring morn, this Lady was thrown upon
this ſhore. I opened the Coffin, found theſe rich jewels,
recovered her, and placed her here in Diana’s Temple.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: May we ſee them?

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Great ſir, they ſhall be brought you to my houſe,
whether I invite you, look, Thaiſa is recovered.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: O, let me look if he be none of mine, my ſanƈtity
will to my ſence bend no licentious ear, but curb it ſpight
of ſeeing: O my Lord, are you not Pericles? like him
you ſpeak, like you are: did you not name a tem-
peſt, a birth, and death?

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: The voice of dead Thaiſa.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: That Thaiſa am I, ſuppoſed dead and drown’d.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Immortal Dian!

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: Now I know you better, when we with tears part-
ed Pentapolis, the King my father gave you ſuch a ring.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: This, this, no more, you gods, your preſent
kindneſſe makes my paſt miſeries ſport, you ſhall do
well, that on the touching of her lips I may melt, and
no more be ſeen; O come, be buried a ſecond time with-
in theſe armes.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My heart leaps to be gone into my mothers
boſome.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Look who kneels here, fleſh of thy fleſh, Thaiſa,
Thy burden at the ſea, and call’d Marina for ſhe was
yielded there.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: Bleſt, and mine own.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Hail Madam, and my Queen!

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: I know you not.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: You have heard me ſay when I did fly from
Tyre, I left behind an ancient ſubſtitute; can you remem-.
ber what I call’d the man, I have nam’d him oft.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: ’Twas Hellicanus then.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Still confirmation, embrace him, dear Thaiſa,
this is he, now do I long to hear how you were found?
how poſſibly preſerved? and who to thank (beſides the
gods) for this great miracle?

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: Lord Cerimon, my Lord, this man through
whom the gods have ſhewn their power, that can from
firſt to laſt reſolve you.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Reverend ſir, the gods can have no mortal offi-
cer more like a god than you, will you deliver hwo this
dead Queen re-lives?

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: I will, my Lord, beſeech you firſt go with me un-
to my houſe, where ſhall be ſhewn you all was found with
her; how ſhe came plac’ſt here in the Temple, no need-
full thing omitted.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Pure Dian bleſſe thee for thy viſion, and will offer
night oblations to thee; Thaiſa, this Prince, the fair be-
trothed of your daughter, ſhall marry at Pentapolis, and
now this ornament that makes me look diſmal, will I clip
to forme, and what this fourteen years no razor toucht,
to grace thy marriage day, I’le beautifie.

speech.speaker: Thai.
speech.line: Lord Cerimon hath letters of good credit, Sir,
my father’s dead.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Heavens make a Star of him, yet here, my Queen,
we’ll celebrate their Nuptials, and our ſelves will in that
kingdome ſpend our following dayes; our ſon and
ſhall in Tyrus reign.
Lord Cerimon, we do our longing ſtay,
To hear the reſt untold, Sir, lead’s the way.
In Antiochus and his daughter, you have heard

line.italic: Of monſtrous luſt, the due and juſt reward:

speech.line: In Pericles his Queen and daughter ſeen,

line.italic: Although aſſayl’d with Fortune fierce and keen,
Vertue preferred from fell deſtruƈtions blaſt,
Led on by heaven, and crown’d with joy at laſt.

speech.line: In Hellicanus may you well deſcry,

line.italic: A figure of truth, of faith, of loyalty:

speech.line: In reverend Cerimon there well appears,

line.italic: The worth that learned charity aye wears.

speech.line: For wicked Cleon and his wife, when Fame

line.italic: Had ſpread his curſed deed, the honor’d name

speech.line: Of Pericles, to rage the City turn,

line.italic: That him and his, they in his Pallace burn:
The gods for murder ſeemed ſo content,
To puniſh, although not done, but meant.
So on your patiences evermore attending,
New joy wait on you, here our play hath ending.

personae.persona: Marina daughter to Pericles and Thaiſa.
Leonine a Murtherer, ſervant to Dioniſia.
Diana, a goddeſſ appearing to Pericles.
Knights tilting in Honor of Thaiſa.
